headline: Great company for a career start | Awesome tech stack to work on | Slightly disoriented
pros:
- VMware is a market leader in server virtualization and hypervisor. Clearly wanting to headspear the public and hybrid cloud management too.
- Never in my tenure I faced any kind of Managerial micromanaging or mistreatment. Managers do follow the EPIC2 values.
- Great opportunity to learn and skill yourself in Storage, Networks and Virtualization domain. 
- Good engineering peer
- Company culture is really good
- Great Work Life Balance ( Depends on the team )
cons:
- At the present moment, VMware's sense of direction is a bit hazy. vSphere and vMotion were game changers. But now it needs something for the third act.
- Losing its mojo
- A bit too flexible, every team has their own silos of work nobody knows about. No concrete design framework

cons: Significant leadership departures over the past 18 months (CEO, COO, CTO, CMO, Head of Sales, etc.), combined with a transformative change in the business model as the company adopts SaaS. It's going well, but this has caused uncertainty and turnover across the company.

headline: Pioneering Company that continues to Innovate and Lead & Growth Mindset Culture
pros:
-EPIC2 Values - Execution Passion Integrity Customers Community - It is the foundation of the company's culture, and everyone believes in them.
-Culture - it's hard to put into words the people and the way they are constantly striving to be better overall - always learning, always sharing, always passionate, always about the customer, always :)
-Challenging Opportunity - VMware was a bucket list company for me, and it still is. The opportunities are always challenging and rewarding.
-People - The People at VMware are Truly Fantastic! They live the EPIC2 values, and they inspire me when lucky enough to hear their stories
-Work/Life Balance - the company has put in increased effort to stress this during the pandemic, and it is greatly appreciated. We had an EPIC2 week off at end of 2021 to celebrate the season & holidays with our families.
cons:
- It's a fairly large organization, so at times you may find that different groups are working on the same challenge without knowing others were working on the same. It's now always bad, but it is at times. 
-There is a saying that the "cream rises to the top", but what about when it's all cream? There are so many talented employees that at times promotions may be delayed since many are qualified for the next step. This can lead to some hurt feelings.

headline: Love the values; execution needs work
pros:
They give you a ton of days off and really value diversity and inclusion. 
Great pay, benefits and people. Great technology.
cons:
The most disorganized company I’ve ever worked for; we’ve had a massive leadership change and the turnover hasn’t stopped; they can’t figure out why but here it is in a nutshell: we’re a mess. 

Enablement is horrible; all focused on big picture strategy but doesn’t give you the tools you need to actually close against competitors. You can’t get in front of professionals and spout high level strategy every meeting, we need to know the how. Getting a quote built and out the door is a week-long process and upper management complains about how time consuming it is to constantly approve quotes; here’s an idea, have set thresholds. If discounts are within a set threshold don’t have a human clicking the box; save that for the deep discounts that require a manual touch. 

Deal reg program and partner program are labyrinths that make no sense. The person in charge of de-complicating the program quit after the last re-vamp and I believe may have checked out long before departure; there have been recent changes but when changes are made it’s reactionary and they don’t see the repercussions until it’s too late & it’s not very partner friendly.
Sales has hit their number yet their rolling out new metrics that micromanage and make it harder to do your job and only looks at certain output that doesn’t necessarily correlate with closing business. If you hired us to do a job, expect we’re doing it and if we’re not hitting our numbers then I can understand asking for us to log every single thing. They claim it’s for uniformity and consistency, sure. Way too many emails, meetings, last minute all hands and lack of collaboration/communication across the business units. Lots of pressure, lots of red tape and lots of obstacles and too much busy work. Way too many bundles and things to learn and with the amount of turnover we’ve had it’s hard to find people to go to for help. 
It’s really hard to get your job done here and I hope we see things “ease up” a bit from the micromanagement perspective. When you value logging calls/meetings quantity over quality, you really don’t give the time and space needed to go after larger more strategic accounts. It becomes just another large corporation trying to fit reps into a box. We’re having strategy conversations on moves that have millions of dollars tied to them and it takes a lot of coordination internally because we’re such a mess. I’ve actually chipped a tooth in my sleep from clenching and I’ve never had this issue. I believe in our vision but the stress isn’t worth it. These products take time to learn and if the turnover doesn’t stop it’s hard to get the support you need to close deals & creates s ton of unnecessary stress. Right now I would tell anyone I care about to stay away and I may be looking if things don’t improve by q2.

headline: VMware Management Review
pros: VMware is a rich company with large cash flows from Vshpere software licensing renewals and licensing growth in both private and public cloud. VMware's base salary, compensation for overachievement, and options packages are very competitive. Pat G. the prior CEO did brilliant work to build out the Vsphere domain within Hyperscalers.
cons: Typical sales cycle takes 6-12 months and VMware resets sales goals every 6 months, so many sales people (70-80%) never attain goal. Account teams with customers who are rapidly growing their licensing requirements or require re-licensing Vsphere in a hyperscaler can hit goal. VMware marketing is invisible or non-existant to most customers and to the field org. Go to market motion with channel is completely broken. Channel parters don't trust or understand how to grow business with VMware and actively sell against the VMware in many market segments (REL, F5, Crowdstrike, more). Sales management talks a good game (value selling and more), but in action it is mostly a churn and burn sales motion where field teams hover over accounts, harvest an ELA, and then try to dump the account to another sales team who will babysit the customre until the next ELA. The company makes enough money and realizes enough growth from Vshpere, that the other products are not effectively advertised, marketed, or supported by sales campaigns. Lying is tolerated and sometimes rewarded in the sales organization. The CEO communicates with the company by posting a 16 page manifesto, seems to lack a basic understanding of how to fix the go to market problems, and seems to be an engineer.

headline: I don't recognise the company everybody else is talking about
pros: I'm happy for the people who've left enough positive reviews for VMware to win a UK Glassdoor award this year, but I guarantee you that none of them work in support.
cons: In support we get treated like absolute dirt. The management has spent the last 2-3 years pushing people into working 12-14 hour days, and then using the productivity of the people who do so as a stick to beat everybody else with. KPIs are set which are literally impossible to meet without devoting every waking minute to the job, and if they aren't met, you need to justify why you would dare to have a family, hobbies, or a healthy sleep schedule. Training on the product is extremely minimal, assuming you have time to actually do it (we don't). There are no avenues to ask for help if you're struggling, either in a technical sense or a personal sense. There is absolutely zero collaboration between agents or departments, unless you're lucky enough to be able to ask a personal friend (which obviously means that anybody acting as a potential escalation point is constantly playing favourites, and will almost certainly just ignore you if you've never been out drinking with them). Multiple people have been signed off long-term because the job has destroyed their health, and many more have simply walked away from the company. None of those positions have been backfilled; their work is simply piled up onto people who can't cope with what they already have, until they break down too. Customers regularly complain about the poor service they're getting, but management never step in to address these complaints, either internally or with the customer directly. It could not be more obvious that the company simply doesn't care about us.

headline: Difficulty retaining talent
pros:
- Previously good WLB
- Good benefits
- Flexible WFH options
- Lots of opportunities to move internally
- Lots of opportunity to learn
- There may be some opportunity in the uncertainty of long term outlook post DELL spinoff

NOTE: Most of the above has been negatively affected lately as employees leave for much better opportunities
cons:
- High turnover right now with many people leaving for more pay and less stressful work (which is caused by people leaving. Creates a vicious cycle of people leave, we have trouble hiring, work gets distributed to team, someone gets burned out and leaves for a better opportunity, repeat)
- Decreasing WLB due to added work
- More pressure on the business leaders which then gets passed on to technical leaders and teams
- Decent pay, but honestly with low stock performance, many are leaving to pursue more lucrative offers. Many peers are leaving for 1.5x - 2.0x TC
- CEO does not inspire confidence post DELL spin off
- WLB previously was good, but early morning and late night calls can be killer over time.

headline: Certain about our uncertainty
pros: Mostly solid technology, opportunity to make money, focus on employee well being. There are still some really smart people here.
cons: VMware continues to lose valuable talent at every level, from CEO down to individual contributors. This is a place that no longer attracts the industry's best and brightest minds. Open positions are now backfilled with 3rd stringers from hardware backgrounds (HP/IBM/insert random irrelevant technology company here). The result are leaders and teams of people who have limited software experience and do not understand the technology landscape or platforms VMware provides. In the end we get dysfunctional cross-sectional teams who are largely mismanaged, unhappy, don't attain quota, and feel unfulfilled. headline: Seriously, do NOT work here. This company's management is disgusting.
pros: It's a work from home position.
cons:
VMware is like a cult. They lure you in by telling you that they are all a family and you are now a part of it. They subtly exploit their employees in sneaky ways that you don't realize they're doing it until you're out of there. 

My manager and his boss (this was in the Federal TAM team in Reston, Virginia) forced us into 8-9 hour meetings NON STOP with no breaks besides a short lunch break. The meetings have ABSOLUTELY NOTHING TO DO WITH THE JOB. LITERALLY NOTHING. THEY JUST SHOEHORN US INTO DAILY NONSTOP MEETINGS FOR ZERO REASON. My manager and his boss made us order painting supplies with our own money (and they said they'll reimburse us later...2-3 weeks later) and forced us to do a "painting and chatting session" with them and my coworkers for THREE HOURS AFTER THE WORK DAY ENDED. When I think back to this moment, I'm starting to question if they have narcissistic personality disorder or they never had enough love and attention as children that they want it from their subordinates whom they have power over. 

My manager assured us MULTIPLE times that we CAN keep our cameras off during these nonstop meetings that distract from actual work and that we only need to pay attention to the meeting. Then, my manager would meet with me privately on the side and berate me for not having my camera on. He'd also get aggressive with me over zoom and look at me angrily and give me evil eye stares and slam his desk with with fists HARD. He also rolled his eyes at me multiple times and he gives dirty looks to my other female coworkers (I'm female). I think he's secretly a misogynist. 

The sneaky part is that they micromanage you but give you the illusion that you are not being watched. Every few weeks, there a multiple performance reviews given out by meeting leaders to the managers. 

But the worst part is, my manager and his boss randomly fired me because I wasn't being a team player (in other words, I wasn't going to be exploited to their whims). I stood up to them and the next week, they fired me. My manager blocked me. His boss blocked me. There was no explanation. Just a termination. You should see the houses they live in. Multi million dollar houses. The week after he fired me, my manager had a two week vacation to Ecuador while I was struggling to pay for my sick parents who can longer pay their rent. And the worst part of it all is that they told me that they would never fire me because they made me go through 4 BS interviews and they like me and want to invest in my future career. My manager and his boss are lying, cheating, rich scum who need to be taken down to learn a lesson. 

My coworkers are not any better. I had one coworker who seemed to be the leader of the subordinates and she'd schedule nonsense meetings ON THE WEEKEND. My manager said those were optional meetings, but then, as usual, he berated and embarrassed me in front of his boss at me for not joining. My coworkers would also create more work projects AFTER THE WORK THE DAY WAS OVER and contact me on my personal cell phone AFTER THE WORK DAY WAS OVER for NON EMERGENCIES.

I really, really, really want to reveal my manager's name and his boss's name so that you know to NEVER work for them (even if they leave VMware to torture other employees at other companies). However, I'm waiting until I settle myself financially so that my future is not jeopardized. When that settles, I'll write a review again here and reveal their full names. My manager's last name is Miller and his boss's last name is Boertlein. Stay the heck away from VMware and them. They're a toxic and failing company. 

Please, please, please, please listen to my warning when I say to avoid VMware at all costs (seriously only work here if you have no better options). This is not a joke review. I want to ensure that others see this review before deciding to apply to VMware or take a job there.

And I hope you will avoid my former manager and his boss. Both equally nasty people who need severe empathy training.

headline: Great tech spoiled a little by overcompensation of "wokeness"
pros: Great software, great people, great ethos. The company is run extremely well from financial/planning perspective - at least in the sales part....
cons:
Too much "woke"-ness. Too much focus on PODs for every single group of humans imaginable. Great idea in theory, but it inevitably makes many people feel like they are -ist and just didn't know it yet - but there's a training course that will point out why you are a -ist. 

I would like everyone to be judged on how they behave, how they treat others, their experience and suitability for a role, celebrating differences and cultures etc but not use it as a battering ram. I've marked Diversity and Inclusion as 5 stars because they put so much focus on it, I just personally think it does more harm than good and fosters negativity.  Not necessarily a reason to not join or to leave, but just be aware...

headline: Good company, very busy

Benefits like time off, trailing/tuition reimbursement(after 1-year of employment), flexible work location options since covid, ​plenty of time off including random extra days or even weeks off that don't use regular PTO. 
Management, I think they train them to manage employees in a certain way that makes for a great work atmosphere, they are more helpful and respectful than managers at other companies.
Career growth opportunities for those who put in the effort.
Good company culture, and some of the best coworkers I've worked with.
cons:
Like most companies, they keep Technical Support roles just barely staffed to get the work done. We have enough workload to take 40-45 hours per week most of the time. That is the major con for most people and can be fairly stressful at the busiest of times.
More recently they said we fall under the Fed Executive Order vaccine mandate, and ALL employees must be fully vaccinated by January 18th or could lose their job, so may not be a good place to work if you don't want the shot.

headline: Every workplace has pros and cons. Weigh what you value
pros:
- Great work/life balance
- Supportive of mental health/disabilities
- Best manager I've ever had (MAPBU)
- Celebrates different races/cultures regularly
- Getting better at remote work
- Opportunity to rotate between business units/internal teams if you want to try something new
- Amazing benefits (such as 3 months parental leave)
- Generous budget for mental/physical wellness
cons:
- Product release process is gated and slow
- Change is also slow and/or progress is not well communicated
- "Culture" is a hard question to answer, because it can vary widely between business units (BUs) 
- "Time to Deploy" can also vary widely between BUs
- Preaches "EPICC" values for employees, but no action is taken if those are violated
- Noted avoidance of questions that they don't want to answer on multiple occasions
- A lot of company infrastructure levels and they are changed often
- Promotion is based on "need for the position". Decisions appear to be made not on talent, effort, or impact but on how visible/lauded that impact was
- Company meetings with the CEO appear to involve a lot of sucking-up and lavished praise, which can be kind of uncomfortable to witness
- Getting better, but would like to see more of a practice what you preach mentality rather than just acknowledgment of issues
- Government contracts appear to dictate policy and direction more than other contracts (maybe this is a pro for others)
- Politics are encouraged on one political side, and silenced on the other. Have witnessed some employees connecting in external groups or privately because they do not feel safe in the normal working environment.

VMW is trying very hard to change direction. It's a process and takes time. If you are a newbie and ready to play with the wave of change this is your job! Even so, VMw is still a good company that even paid out my entire bonus after my leaving with no inquiries or discussions, really impressed!

headline: EUC legacy tech, slow moving
pros:
- You'll learn quite a lot in terms of software engineering processes, coding practices, designs but you can also learn these things at other companies too.
- The people are very friendly and is always down to help you out. I really learned quite a lot from them.
- I've only had great managers who acts immediately on feedback, makes you feel valued as an employee
- Excellent benefits, 1k annual wellbeing allowance, 5k Take 1 allowance (for conferences and certification programs), internet reimbursement, 6% 401k match, Health, Dental, Vision all covered...etc
cons:
PLEASE NOTE This is about the EUC department:
- Lots of legacy tools, monolithic architecture, and unstable build pipeline, and slow builds. Releases are constantly being delayed and the UI is less than desirable.
- Modernization effort projects are only assigned to senior and staff level engineers and the rest of the engineering team are left with maintaining the monolith and adding new features to it.
- Very little diversity across engineering
- Culture is non-existent especially with the remote type workforce. Makes it really difficult to connect with coworkers are most personalities are very passive

headline: Slave drivers!

I was promised raises and bonuses that never materialized. I ended up leaving for the same position with another firm for a 50% increase in pay. Years later I applied, was told my needed salary was well within the pay range for the role, only to be told that my minimum was "too much". headline: Hard to Understand Where VMware is Heading
pros: VMware is relatively competitive with regard to salary and benefits. The company also has a large footprint in existing customers with a few products that continue to be stalwarts to enterprise IT. That's where the "pros" end.
cons: Since the departure of Pat Gelsinger VMware continues to fall apart from the inside out. VMware has continued to bring in tone-deaf executives who have no idea about how to sell in the industry. The continued messaging around "multi-cloud" is hard to swallow. VMware hardly competes in cloud and the product set that is available doesn't do anything for customers truly looking to leverage multi-cloud, it is frustrating to listen to executives continue to parrot a message that VMware doesn't have product or expertise with. Post-Gelsinger VMware's current CEO has decided to bring in executives far below the caliber of those that left. Many executives who were many-year Cisco veterans that couldn't shift Cisco back into relevance are, apparently, here to inspire us all with their progressive market experience? They don't seem to understand the technology, market or customers. A trifecta for VMware, but not the kind you want. Raghu is a non-charismatic leader who has done nothing to fix the systemic problems VMware had before his leadership started and since taking the helm has made things worse with poor leadership choices and a push for products that don't sell and a move to focus on SaaS and subscriptions for no other reason than to cater to the street. It seems VMware is waiting for someone to come buy them and in the mean time executives are bringing in friends to garner a pay day they likely don't deserve.

headline: All façade and no character in Australia
pros:
The VMware title as an employer carries weight. It’s good to get the brand on your CV and then exit, as there aren’t many transferrable skills to be accumulated by working here. It’s just a good stepping stone, as I have seen while I was working here. Many come by and move on to bigger and better roles brandishing the logo on their CVs
Corporate health care is very good. Other benefits are less than average. Shopping discounts are no better than holding the Frequent Values membership. I found out I had better shopping discounts from my insurance company. They have a few extra days off for COVID, but so do many other IT organisations
Onboarding was a relatively seamless experience. However, don’t expect any support from management. You must raise a ticket for everything, and it’s outsourced
Offices are nice, but they are not being used any longer due to COVID workplace restrictions.
If you are highly technical and drink from the VMware cool-aid, you’ll be promoted to very senior technical positions that pay handsomely. If you’re not technical, it’s tough to obtain a managerial position. VMWare prefers to hire externally for senior roles. And if you’re not a white Australian, you’re especially disadvantaged
cons:
The people based in the Australian region are very superficial. You must be part of the clique, a very tight and conceited group led by immature accounts and salespeople.
There are almost no opportunities for internal candidates unless you’re willing to polish an arrogant manager’s ego. The Talent Acquisition team does not even call back unsuccessful internal hires and completely ignores referrals. They are a group of stuck up airheads who are more interested in kissing up to sales managers who are equally superficial.
Many senior people are high on their flatulence, trying to act like the most intelligent person in the room. Not because they are competent or experienced, but more so because everyone is constantly on guard looking over their shoulders, trying not to get stabbed in the back.
Company EPIC2 principles are a total sham and are there for bragging rights only. In other global offices, leaders are noticeably more sincere and do have a high level of integrity. But the Australian managers are probably the worst of any company I have ever worked for. They act like narcissists who will only do charitable work if they can showboat it to invite accolades internally and on LinkedIn.
The result is a high turnover of staff, especially in the Melbourne office. Talented people are constantly leaving for better-run organisations like Microsoft, Salesforces, Splunk, Google and AWS. 
Almost NO diversity in Australia. The place is entirely run by white Australians who try and act cool and hip. Occasionally, they’ll play the ‘inclusion’ card to seem like they’re doing the right thing. But nothing long term or of significant benefit to the people they’re trying to ‘help’. The non-white workers are just there to do the low-end monkey work and fill non-influential roles.

headline: Politics , intimidation and condescending  attitude
pros: They had good policy from optics per se. Like they will give you latest macbook , gym reimbursement  and may be couple of foreign trips
cons:
They take pride in saying they are tech companies. They want to compete with AWS but look at the way their CEO talk . When AWS talk they can speak the language of business while these guys can not. The story start and end with server virtualisation.

Top management is not talking business outcome and hence complete middle management only talks about technology. This creates a issue in connecting with business at customer side. Also they treat badly people who does not have hardcore technical background.

You should join this company till the time you do not get into proper IaaS org like AWS and Azure.

They have a very good building in Bangalore and that they use at marketing tool for new joiner. They will show you some people sleeping in one room but honestly you feel that room at mortuary.

They have six month probation and they will decide on confirmation in five month and can show you door in five months. 

And to do this they will collect scripted evidence against you that you are non performer. They will collect five/ six mails against you and prove your non performance.

Their core sales team insult and humiliate services team. They treat them as their servants.
 
In name of diversity they have hired non competent female leaders . So while lot of strong male employees work as ordinary staff female becomes boss.

headline: A company at crossroads after COVID19
pros:
- Known for having a strong branding in the industry and reputable.
- Generally, the upper management are very warm and welcoming towards everyone. Most seniors in the office are approachable and willing to share their knowledge/experience. 
- Work-life balance? (Depends on the project/account assigned to the individual). Commendable non-monetary benefits.
- A very good starting place for those aspires to do sales in the tech industry, with somewhat hand-holding guidance for fresh graduates. As for experienced hires, commission rates are good. 
- Networking with one another is very much encouraged. Also, some departments/teams are well-bonded. Company-wide get-together events are aplenty.
cons:
- For those who are in non-commission based role, the culture can feel pretty salesy. Strong emphasis on driving sales revenues and selling more to existing customers. Many sales stakeholders involved in an account/project from a tech perspective. 
- A myriad of products which seems to have no value-adding to customers but strongly marketed as premium. Client-facing roles can be expected to know a lot of these products and how to use them. 
- Previously, for graduates, salaries are below market rate of those majoring IT/CS. However, the rates might have improved in the recent few years. That said, career progression, together with salary hikes, seem relatively slow in comparison to other less reputable companies.
- A growing obsession with IT certification lately.
- Personally encountered some HR staff who do not act very professionally.

headline: NSX engineer
pros:
Working on cutting edge technologies NSX.

Lots of trainings on products.

Plenty of companies adopting NSX, good future too.

Permanent/hybrid WFH option.

Best company for all the departments in vmware, except Tech support engineers, GSS Global Support Service.
cons:
Unmanageable number of case tickets.

Freaking lots of stress and pressure.

You will not be able to take breaks, 99% of the time you will work for 9+ hours a day. Without breakfast/coffee/lunch etc.. occupied on customers call throughout day.

Management knows how much engineers are busy, but they will not solve this issue 100%.

Don't expect work life balance.

When compared to amount of work/stress, Salary paid is only close to standard of market or could be less. 

For salary vmware pays, it would be good if you move outside, as there are lots of other companies paying better than what vmware pays and gives you better positions to work, while maintaining a good work life balance.

Within team, same level of position and same level experience engineers will be making different numbers interms of salary.

headline: It's all downhill from here
pros: Starting pay, benefits, work from home option
cons:
You can see the culture going downhill. It used to be a good place to work but they keep forcing more and more Dell folks to come onboard and it's becoming unbearable to work here. Management used to describe working here as "having the feel of a start up but the stability of a large company". Senior/C-Suite leadership is leaving left and right. Pay and benefits are no longer competitive. Diversity and inclusion programs are just for show. Management doesn't actually care about DEI. Promotions are based on who you know and how well you say "yes" to everything.

No well thought out path for career progression. Everyone is new so if you're tenured, you're always teaching other people what to do. People cycle in and out. This isn't a place to build a career.

headline: So. Much. Potential. (But, so much politics)
pros: This SHOULD be a great company. It's got a great set of culture values, killer products, a devoted customer group, excellent diversity mindset, and enough growth to give opportunity for people to move up. Plus, they pay really, really well, allow you to work remotely, and have a strong strategy for the future.
cons: But, there seems to be this core group of toxic people that Will. Not. Leave. (maybe because they know they have burned their networks outside the company). And they manage to keep getting promoted by making it miserable for everyone else, and basically outlasting them. The result is an org with very few "doers" and a lot of "maneuverers" that make themselves look good by packaging the work of others. In addition, they have some serious growing pains to go through - there's a lot of stuff that takes waaaaaaaay longer than it should because leadership won't organize around a process that reflects their size.

The India mid-level management team is highly inefficient and has no clue on what's happening in the company and they just keep changing processes going around in circles. 

There is no value for experienced and knowledgeable employees like old days, and the main focus is just on college hires. Some college hires are getting more salary than 7-8 years experienced people in the same team. Most of the promotions/appraisals are based on office politics and how much you can impress the manager, rather than your work.

Hiring unqualified people only because they were from a particular neighbouring state or they were relatives of someone they know is common in PSO ops, deal desk teams etc. Even though I personally didn't face any discrimination and I earned decent salary, I quit only because of the low quality of work offered and the unprofessional environment. Hard to focus on execution when you are being coerced from the top level to change your views on traditional family values often including graphic visuals (latest corp. training videos anyone!? what was that about) , mandatory training on topics such as unconscious bias and guessing critical race is likely next

VMware was focused, friendly, open and generous in giving back under Pat. What the hell happened this past year!? Whoever is pushing the changes, those invisible hands that have impacted the world, has introduced division to a level I have never seen before in my 20+ years in this industry and I have worked in some pretty harsh environments

Bonuses are taken from non-indian and given to indians. I am a current employee and I have seen how the VPs and Directors control promotions with clear racist practices.

A lot of reports were sent to the vmware to investigate. What is the outcome? more toxic and alienation of employees who complain that their bonuses are stolen. More retaliation.

Many employees had their bonus stolen this round of March/April 2021 and given to the directors indian friends.
cons:
This is as toxic as it gets. Retaliation if anyone speaks up against the racism and favoritism.

Competency does not matter. Race matters. If you are indian, you will get 120% bonus. If you are non indian you will get 80% bonus.

It is obvious, easy, and clear.

headline: EPIC and Awesome
pros: VMware is one of those companies that really give you a sense of job satisfaction as they don't just talk the talk but also walk the walk which is evident in their great EPIC2 culture. Good salaries, benefits,  career and personal development programs are amongst one of the best on offer in the industry. I have thoroughly enjoyed everyday since I joined as you are exposed to great products and services which are very good for one's resume. Despite Pat Gelsinger leaving as CEO, I still believe the future is very bright for the company.
cons: Workload can be a bit overwhelming sometimes and training/ enablement initiatives can be a bit overwhelming as there is just too many on offer. I want to believe career progression is based on merit and down to one's hardwork but I sense there could be a bit of politics and favoritism in some quarters. There could be an improvement in Diversity, Equality and inclusion especially within senior and executive management positions.

It appears like VMware has a play book when it buys out a company, and none of it helps the employees of the buyout. The first thing they will do is try to re-band (demote) the employees. They will use the excuse of they are a big company and things are different and you either take it or leave it. After a few months they will double the old company’s workload and ramp up offshore efforts to help. 
Upper management will trash talk the bought-out company any chance they get in order to justify any changes (layoffs and reorg) they will implement. Upper management will shield themselves from the bought-out company’s managers and employees so they can ignore their issues, concerns or complaints. They will make the bought-out company’s managers accountable to the deliverables but have no responsibility or power, understanding or control of new offshore resources. Management who can, leave the company or quickly find a more stable group in VMWare to transfer to, leaving a huge leadership vacuum. As the bought-out company star team members leave, they will be replaced by untrained resources amplifying unreasonable schedules. 

The new offshore resources will be dumped onto projects with no training or understanding of the project, team or technology. The team will not be integrated or even introduced to each other and will not be given clear goals or direction but will be given multiple and often conflicting deadlines and goals. The new offshore resources will have their own managers who have no goals or accountability to the new projects and often have goals and accountability for other projects. The bought-out employees will be squeezed into having to do their previously scheduled deliverables, new deliverables and somehow ramp up themselves on new products, VMware systems and help the new team (assigned 2 minutes ago) also ramp up. 

If they fail on any of the three projects you are on, they will be called out for not being “team player”. If they mention any organizational problems, they will be called much worse things. Upper management will berate you if you have even hint at questioning them, they will call you hostile, ironically screaming it at you. A person asked a simple question about unfreezing pay raises and an SVP went on a rage about cooperation and not being hostile. Its common for five hundred people to be on an engineering conference call and if the SVP doesn’t filibuster the whole meeting to avoid questions no one bothers to waste their energy to ask a question or from fear of reprisal. Teams and information are silo-ed across teams and even from management to engineers. It’s not uncommon for issues to ferment or fester for months and only when it’s a crisis gets dumped on the engineers who can actually fix it with demands of why several month long outstanding issue has not been resolved, when the engineers didn’t even know about it until that moment. 

Once the ramp up is done, upper management expects quick results from the untrained disorganized mess they created. This is when some directors start working against each other. Some openly subvert and work against others to see which of them survives the next re-org or twice a year layoff. Upper management entire focus is on solving “their” problems and “their” goals, often to the detriment of the product, employees, team or even company.

As someone who has helped build a successful decade long offshore program, this is not how to do it. Upper management creates such an environment of fear from over aggressive schedules, and priority contradictions, poor communication, unwillingness to listen, layoffs, and hostility towards the bought-out company it fails before it starts. 

VMWare used the 2020 financial crisis to temporarily freeze 401k matching, bonuses, and raises all while exceeding their goals.

headline: Typical big company, with atypical benefit cuts / promotion cancellation
pros: Donation matching is a concretely good bright spot in a company that, contrastingly, has "no ethical limit" to its business (straight from CEO Pat in an AMA!)
cons:
"We'll work with Saudi Arabia and North Korea, and if you don't like it, go somewhere else." A direct quote from leadership. I see a lot of reviews here being very positive on culture and values. Why? VMware donated to political candidates this year who oppose free access to abortion and called slavery "a necessary evil." Mitch McConnell got VMware cash. We want to work with authoritarian regimes. 4.2 stars for company values btw.

But enough about values - your average Silicon Valley job seeker cares about money (I used to live there, I can say this). VMware cut 401k matching, and canceled promotions and pay raises for a full year due to the pandemic. That'd make sense, if our profits suffered, but they didn't, they topped estimates. Great! Well at least our stock - oh, it's been flat for 2 years. We're a tech company right?

Well, the market might be right on this one. VMware doesn't have an exciting future, and it might not have a bright one. Will containers and Kubernetes kill virtual machines? They're at least going to do some damage. Watching from the inside as VMware scrambled to stand up "Tanzu", its own brand of Kubernetes that no one has ever heard of, has proven to me they're worried. I have no reason to believe Tanzu is anything revolutionary. It seems much more likely this is a company that peaked in one technology and will be behind the curve in the new one, for the foreseeable future.

If you're a VMware employee, rejoice! There are many, many better companies out there - if you think VMware is good just wait till you see them. If you're not a VMware employee, I hope this perspective has provided some contrast to the mindless one-liner reviews. Chances are you have some other options - maybe give those another look.

headline: Compensation is great, Technology is interesting, but regular layoffs/reorgs
pros:
* Compensation & benefits are excellent
* The tech you get to work on is interesting, and is always growing/changing (both from innovation and frequent acquisitions of smaller companies)
* People are mostly very smart
cons:
* There are annual layoffs, usually in January - seen a lot of people with tons of product knowledge get axed
* Related to this, there seem to be constant reorgs - mostly this affects the people above you, but it can be difficult to keep track of what groups/divisions within the company you belong to
* The frequent acquisitions, which have some positive effects (see above) also mean that there are constantly new teams of people that need to be integrated, and that can lead to more confusion and disorganization

headline: Do not work here in Sales
pros:
Decent pay, select cool people (although pretty rare), okay snacks (lagging behind heavily when it comes to most tech companies). Good working from home flexibility.

Maybe their Palo Alto campus has a better culture?
cons:
Terrible leadership in sales (for the most part. A couple good ones here and there), people quit all the time, constant restructuring and layoffs, doesn't hire very smart people, bad training, a lot of people in sales especially higher up leadership is very entitled and formal without any sort of desire to seem like genuine people.

Also, the internal processes are stuck in 1999 and are terribly inefficient and unclear. It makes it very frustrating to get anything done here as an employee and it makes it extremely hard to do your job.

A lot of people here seem fake, and most don't actually care about making employees feel valued. A lot of people have left the company because they couldn't stand this anymore, along with all the other bad stuff.

I've met met some of the worst managers of my entire life working here. The company knows horrific people like this work here and are too scared to do anything about it.

All the good talent is leaving because they know they can find a better experience anywhere else.

headline: Discouraged
pros: Big company, near industry monopoly, so stable place to work for now.
cons: Leadership runs the business like the military. If you’re inspired by such motivational gems as “this is war”, you’ll be happy. I find this worldview repulsive. Leadership says one thing to your face and does the opposite in private. Employees do not feel safe to ask questions or express contrary views. Leadership is incentivized to compete for resources; lots of infighting, fiefdoms, and empire building. Solving customer problems does not appear to be a priority; investment decisions are made by architects. Very discouraging place to be a product manager. Too many stories among colleagues of demeaning language from fellow employees, and no action taken when this behavior is reported. No diversity in leadership; all white and Asian men. The responsibility for improving diversity is clearly the burden of women and minorities, as an additional responsibility to their day jobs. On townhall meetings, women are only represented as secretaries, choosing questions for the men to answer. CEO is an evangelical. No meaningful efforts at equitable pay practices; some analyst apparently does an audit, without any understanding of individual’s contribution.

headline: RUN AWAY FROM VMWARE SLED
pros:
Great culture in most of the company outside of SLED organization
Good Insurance
Innovative company
cons:
STAY AWAY FROM VMWARE SLED.

These Drawbacks are specific to SLED - I would highly recommend staying away from State Local Government and Education vertical within VMware. Don't join SLED group within VMware, there are better opportunities within VMware than SLED. SLED Culture and leadership are toxic.

I worked as Solutions Engineer in SLED. During my time, I had pleasure to work with some of the brightest engineers. However, Quota pressures was very high and expectations were unreasonable such as sale a solution that doesn't work or fix a solution that was sold before I started and would have never worked. Solution selling methodology changes every month or quarter, 

You get insane amount of training assignment, be ready to put in 80-90 hours a week. VMware is losing top talent to Amazon, Google, Microsoft and IBM. 

You are expected to be an engineer and account manager at the same time.

I had 3 different bosses during my tenure of less than 2 years. In Midwest SLED practice has revolving door for AEs, SEs and Directors. Senior Directors and SE managers are clueless, VMware is absorbing all the untalented people that ware laid off from Symantec and HPe at various levels, . Incompetent ones end up staying. They are able to recruit new talent by telling them story of great opportunities and almost everyone buys into it due to VMware's reputation only to find out most of them were false. Tertiary realignment is very frequent and you lose.

If you have a stable role don't fall for VMware SLED organization and stay where you are. If you are desperate in getting a new job then know that if you go to VMware SLED you might it might be a wobbly stepping stone at the best and you might be better off somewhere else.


During my short time in SLED there were almost 30 people quit or let go out of a team of 45. Average time spent in their role was 8 months.

Velocloud is completely a crooned corporate workplace where no one is interested in your career development. Irrespective of good ideas you discussed, everything will be dusted to trash bin and only senior people has credits. 

Moreover Chennai unit acts as outsourcing to Palo Alto division and PA people treat in the same away and never as peers. Chennai managers go all way to please Bay people rather than customers.

Product management is worse and have no sense of analytics and futuristic view. Clearly avoid this company and do not make the same mistake I did. :)

pros:
VMware acquired our company about a year ago mostly for Cloud Foundry and our customers. They provide a lot of stability and are probably profitable. They have an established client base with their legacy products and are working towards modernizing them with their strategy, "Paving the world in Kubernetes." I believe that they'll get there, but it has been a rough merger with offices and teams being cut as they discover more redundancies through our organization. 

Here are some pros:

1.) Work life balance is pretty good.
2.) People are generally kind
3.) Pay is on par
4.) They have been going all in on WFH during COVID and probably will continue to do so post COVID.
cons:
It's a large corporation, and they see the world as containers. As an app developer, it's been hard being in this environment as they are used to moving slowly and insisting on using bad tooling. 

1.) We've been moving our documents to Office 365 and our email to Outlook (coming from GSuite). Coming from largish start-up, this has been a rough transition, and it just feels stupid. 
2.) Similarly, we are not able to use 3rd party tools and services without approval from finance and IT, and this has been a huge bottleneck, and we have lost our autonomy to make real decisions. (Also IT is based out of India, so there are ridiculously long wait times to get help, so there's that.) They are going to insist we use Jenkins which is so early 2010s, so I'm just over it.
3.) 401k matching has been stopped. Bonuses and promotions frozen even though they have the cash to do a massive stock buyback. It just feels like they want what's best for company's shareholders and executives, but don't care if they affect their employees.

headline: Unfair treatment of non-developers and lack of values in practice
pros:
- Lots of benefits, including an ESPP stock share program
- Good salary overall
cons:
- inadequate management for the Bulgarian geography
- overloading with work which is outside of official job descriptions
- HR and Recruitment teams fail to protect employee rights which results in high levels of exploitation of some employees at the expense of others
- breaching of well-described rules for internal mobility despite a constant narrative of supporting personal growth and mobility across teams. After working for 2 years at the company I tried to move to a higher level position in a better paid job category with a pay range almost twice higher than my current one and they tried to 'offer' me the same salary as my current position. When I cited the official mobility guidelines for them, which state that salary should be readjusted in such situations, asking for a better (or should I say real) offer so as to have an incentive to move out of my current position, they withdrew from the offer because of my motivation being 'mainly financial'.... Thereby questioning my work integrity and conflating it with my professional and human right to earn more as I develop and become more valuable to the company. 
- lack of well-established processes for passing work to technical writers which results in spending hours or days trying to figure out if something has to be documented and what exactly. Incredibly frustrating.
- Absurdly incompetent high-level employees (PMs, TPMs, RMs) that can't type a single sentence without a mistake who constantly try to blur the line between their responsibilities and that of other employees so they can basically do nothing

I could go on and on and on. If salary and benefits is all you're looking for then you might be okay. If, however, you get frustrated by the complete lack of professional culture and adequate management then do yourself a favor and avoid this pile of crap.

headline: Very top-down. Great opportunites being missed.
pros:
Good benefits, holiday, bonus. The money side cannot be faulted.

Lot of community work - very commendable. Great programs for this which are underused by staff, sadly. They have millions they want to give away.

They rule the world and are now Too Big To Fail. So, they will always be around. You may not be however - they have a yearly cull in February and many lose their jobs. The good news is that the redundancy package is very very good.
cons:
Management structure. Basically there were about six levels of management between me and the CEO. My manager had no real power, neither did his manager. There are only very few people making decisions here and they are driven by stats and stats alone.

There is an extreme amount of corporate BS - to the point that I wanted to shout "can you just talk English please". 

VERY American - a European may start giggling at their completely see-through tricks to "motivate". Does this really work for Americans? Example: every question you ask is met with "hey, that is an awesome question". It is then followed by a White House Press meeting style BS line. No humour - they take themselves so seriously.

The poor people in the Bangalore office get a very bad deal and are, quite frankly, abused

These guys run a after-sales technical service system for clients which left me embarrassed to be associated with it - completely unfit for purpose (where I worked they used a chat program as an internal ticketing system! Yep. No kidding!). This is an example of management just imposing stiff without consultation and then wondering why it doesn't work.

headline: You have to like working for large companies
pros: You have to like working for a large, globally distributed company to work at VMware. We can work around the clock as a team and have the security of a massive company behind us. Small errors won't make or break us because our portfolio is huge. For someone with a family who needs that work/life balance with great benefits, it's a great place to work. Even the pandemic hasn't slowed us down. We're still acquiring companies and encouraged to work from home.
cons: We can't pivot quickly. This is not your roommate's startup. We can't cultivate the spirit and enthusiasm of a startup. We do our jobs, but there's little passion. Changing tools or processes globally takes an incredible amount of time an effort. If you like agility, this ain't it. ;)

No matter how many billions company rakes  in every year, there will be annual layoffs period!

headline: Great company to work for...until you don't
pros: Good culture, genuine focus on work/life balance, great executive leadership and vision, adequate benefits, employee stock purchase plan, good resources given when you are laid off.
cons:
Business silos, frequent changing of direction and focus within the BUs and lack of coordination between BUs, suspect sustainability in the long term.

I always loved feeling like part of the team at VMware.  I was there 5 years and felt valued and supported.  I never had a bad annual review and by most measures was going above and beyond.  Our team was periodically recognized as doing excellent work and our skills were absolutely unique in the company.  I would have given a Glassdoor review similar to others you see indicating "no negatives I can think of at this time" …but then I fell victim to January layoffs.  I waited a full year from being laid off to do this review so I would do it for the right reasons.  
There was no reason given other than "restructuring" as others have indicated in their reviews.  My guess is that VMware thinks of its employees as all living in the Bay Area where jobs are plentiful.  It took me 7 months to find another good job and it was very hurtful to my financial situation.  Any goodwill I had for VMware was obviously damaged and I would warn others who are considering VMware that you are at risk of being layed-off as a matter of course rather than based on your performance.  
I feel I also should point out that VMware uses stock as a part of its compensation to retain talent and after going through a layoff,  there is little doubt in my. mind that one of the major goals of the January layoffs is to recuperate your stock (for many of us six-figure + amounts of stock).  It is no coincidence that layoffs happen at a time that immediately precedes the vesting date of stock.  As an example, I would have started vesting less than 30 days after my stated last day of work and every person I talked to affected by the January “restructuring” were in the same boat.  
Another important thing to understand is when you are let go by VMware, you are told that the company will give you resources to hopefully get rehired - which they do.  However, I can tell you I wasted a lot of time applying for jobs internally at VMware and based on the behavior of the hiring managers, I am convinced the burden of my stock was a consideration and put me to the bottom of the queue rather than feeling like my extensive knowledge of VMware and my solid track record wold be a plus.  People I was friendly with wouldn't even give me the time of day and I was nothing but discouraged by people when I would reach out.  I certainly bear fault for not looking outside the company more those first couple of months but I would not recommend spending significant time on those efforts if you find yourself in a similar situation.

I would be particularly careful about joining VMware's bloated corporate marketing team.

cons:
None of them are cons for me, but I can imagine the top ones for most engineers would be:
- It's very 9-6.* For some engineers, this is too early or too rigid of a schedule.
- It's not super remote friendly. You can certainly work remotely sometimes, but if that's a big part of your current lifestyle, that would be hard to maintain.

headline: It isn't perfect, but is definitely a nice place to be
pros:
I would like to start by saying that definitely VMware is a nice place to be. Benefits wise it has it all, the company has no competitors (only Microsoft maybe?). You really have a voice in here and you feel valued as an employee. People/management are very nice in here.

-Tuition reimbursement of $5k per year.
-Insurance
-Onsite gym
-Stocks
-Snacks and beverages for free permanently
-They will take you to the US as soon as you join the company to immerse you into the job culture.
-Constantly organizing food and beer parties
-Performance bonuses
-To be honest I cannot recall all benefits, but there are really a lot. It is really good in this aspect.
cons:
Having said the pros, I will now talk based on my experience as a support engineer: there's a dark side to it (no company can be 100% perfect right?). If you're a support engineer honestly the salary isn't great for the amount of work you do (and it worsens if you land as a contractor); and depending on the team you land, you will find yourself in a very stressful environment. More than certainly you will have to take your work home once or twice per week (it can be more). Or simply stay in the office doing overtime (unpaid). You will be demanded to strive in metrics while workload is immense. If you want to boost your virtualization career, here's the place to be; but be ready to sacrifice your personal time. Bottom line, at the short term it is really demanding and exhausting, but at the long term you can look back at it and realize it was all worth it.
-Salary
-Workload

headline: Mixed Bag
pros:
* Diversity among BUs in terms of the projects and technology focus with some cutting edge stuff happening
* Company is really transforming, history has shown that technology companies that rest on their laurels quickly crash and burn. Based on what is happening in VMware I'm pretty sure VMware won't be one of them
* Decent benefits and salary, RSU grants have really gone hill though, pretty disappointing
cons:
As much as VMware has been transforming technology wise, they still fail to address a lot of the toxicity in the management chain and culture
It is still very much about who you know,  kissing up, not rocking the boat and conforming. The hierarchy is also complex making transparency difficult , there are people who I would say can get away with socializing and not doing much work which can have a severe impact on the morale of those who do it

Then there are the talkers, those who are put in lead positions which actually shouldn't be as they know very little about the projects they are leading yet they will be loud and argumentative often at times making incorrect and sometimes foolish claims but they do it in front of management who just think they are correct because the management doesn't know any better

And the last point is that is now mostly Indian, I don't know what breakdown is in terms of the engineering workforce but given what I see I wouldn't be surprised if it was like 80% or something. Now I have had many Indian coworkers over the years some of them good, some of them bad. But the disproportion at VMware especially in cases where one knows somebody from their home province pulls them over and sets them up in a high level position when they are basically equivalent to a new grad just adds to the toxicity

headline: One rotten apple spoiled the bunch
pros: This company is amazing! Amazing benefits. Great progressive culture and a visionary of a CEO. I would still be there for years to come....if it weren't for my direct manager.
cons: I left solely because of my direct manager. She micro managed, belittled, and down right disrespected individuals on her team and cross functioning teams. She was not a leader and ran her team like a dictatorship. I witnessed her yelling on the phone during online meeting and in no way shape or form embodied the vmware culture. Other people on the other side of the floor would hear her yelling.  work from home is huge at vmware...not on her team. After months of asking for it we could work from home on Wednesdays only if she saw fit. One mistake and she would take the privilege away. Not sure if that was the culture previously before the company was acquired by vmware but sadly vmware HR dragged their feet on correcting the problem. They stood in solidarity with the manager instead of listening to the employees.  She was very aggressive and made the environment very uncomfortable. Talk about being rattled with anxiety before a one on one.  I tried to move to another department but she blocked it. I hear she still has her job but they moved her to be an individual contributor.....nice way to handle the problem.

headline: Stranger things happening
pros:
So, VMware as a company can contribute to a lot of prestige, that's the main reason why you'll find most colleagues here or people outside trying to join. 

The office is currently really small, but we will soon move to a new building.

You have drinks, coffee and tea for free. Many activities are done during the year. Callouts with incentives, good salary, gym, food card and other perks. 

The colleagues are nice, really nice. The trouble are some managers who think too highly of themselves.
cons:
Currently the environment is not nice at all. There are obvious things that are strange. 

Not everyone is treated the same way, from at least some managers you notice straight away who their favourites are, this is not cool as you also notice who they "don't" like, and are therefore treated unfairly. Unfortunately this happens in at least 2 or 3 teams, and no one dares to say anything.

There's generally a lack of vision in the office, which is obvious as this still needs to roll and deploy. But even so, many will start looking for something else the moment 7 or 8 months are over.

Remember, no one leaves the company, but everyone leaves the manager. 

We've seen already some performing colleagues being fired without any logic reason at all. This creates a cloud of doubt over the management's incapacity of growing a person, being good at conflict handling or neutral when taking a decision. What a shame.

headline: Excellent company, but not as good as it could and wants to be
pros: Great environment, friendly culture, strong Diversity and Inclusion & Mental Health focus (not much success though, see cons). Excellent technology, customers trust the brand. Good salary, above-average benefits. Ethical business conduct every step of the way and at all levels.
cons:
For all the effort on D&I and Mental Health... the results are not great. Seeking help is not easy, and pressure is still high no matter what you are going through and what are your challenges (dyslexia, depression,...). The technical teams remain a white-middle-aged men environment, and it feels like women are only there to fulfil a quota. No female SEMs, almost no women in senior technical roles, men driven mentality. Same as other tech companies. There is the hope of change but I have not witnessed real results so far (in 2 years). There also seems to be a gender pay gap issue as well (comparing the same role). These realities make it hard to persevere as a female in tech, which exacerbates the problem.
On more general terms, little appreciation for technical skills. I have seen lots of accolades for sales success but no rewards, visibility or recognition for pure technical role accomplishments.

headline: Find the right manager and you will be happy

The other manager hires people mostly from one specific country.  He avoids Americans probably because his ability to manipulate and oppress them is lesser.  His team is extremely toxic with hand picked idiots on the top.  Idiots who are very loyal to him and will never revolt against him.
cons: Join the right manager's team and be happy. Join the wrong manager's team and expect to descend into a hell of dirty politics and sucking up.

headline: Little plan, all gas
pros: Lots of smart people, interesting solution to insight into your business applications, tied to VMware now.
cons: Bleeding edge, poor vetting of releases, no work life balance, doesn't adhere to own rules; roll untested upgrade to production during dinner time Friday with no upgrades after Thursday afternoon? Yep.  Little documentation b/c managers say not worth doing with changes happening so fast but you fight same fire daily. Run book wrong?  Quietly change it while tossing those who used it under the bus. The db sucks, depending on it basically means looking like your a genius or built on a house of cards; your outlook depends on hour of the day and whether it just broke for the 20th day in a row.  It has broken constantly for more than a year and recovery is the same, but whether or not it makes it is literally a time to pray. One db rollback doubles drain time and once you roll fix you just wait to see if it works. There is nothing you can do but take blame for a crappy db choice made years ago when fix doesn't.   Lots of outsourcing to cheaper hire countries so you work with a lot of  eager but junior people.  Signing out after 13 hours on call to junior team in Europe with daily fire still burning? Not if you want to keep your job.  Expect 15+hr on call days with no extra compensation or extra days off and you will be wondering why dev escalation never showed up and just happened to sleep through the 7 hour all night fire.

headline: Couldn't imagine a better place to work
pros: VMware has a great product portfolio and ethic when it comes to employees. The campus feels like a community here, even though there are almost 1000 people here. Any team I worked in so far and multiple managers generally support extra-curricula activity that is not per se limited to your job description. Employees are trusted to organize their time efficiently. Great collaboration and opportunities. Worked here years ago, and was delighted to get the chance to come back 2 years ago. Would not want to leave.
cons:
Continue to employ skilled managers. I have heard from colleagues that some teams are more enjoyable to work in than others. I have been lucky to be blessed with management so far. 
The only thing certain in VMware is change. It will happen - consistently and always.

headline: Excited!
pros:
My team is composed of very smart and very kind people who work well together. We get stuff done! I've only been here a few months, but they are very understanding of my career change and are helping me learn the ropes and the company as time goes by (even though they were very busy when I first started with many things going on, so I appreciate their help!). 

I get to work from home as much as I want and have yet to take any PTO, but the unlimited PTO option is pretty cool and I look forward to utilizing that in the future when I need to. Orientation was AWESOME, and I learned so many soft skills I didn't even realize I was lacking. This company really seems to care about culture and treating employees with respect. I look forward to using the skills they taught me to help the company in keeping to their high standards. 

It seems from other reviews that managers can make or break your time here. So far my managers and teammates have been nothing less than stellar and just so cool, so I feel my time here will continue to be a 5 star rating. I'm excited to keep learning and honing my skills and giving the best work possible.

The interview process for my position was grueling but honestly I feel in hindsight it was a pro. It really helped to encourage me that my skills were up to par with what they were looking for.
cons: Orientation didn't happen until 3 months after I was hired. Felt very lost as to who and what VMware was exactly, and still am not entirely sure what the different  softwares I'm working on are about (I don't come from a tech background). I've been told a few times but there's so many different ones, and new features constantly being added, and they can sound so complicated that it's hard to keep it all straight. I'm sure with time this will get easier though.

headline: Objective Review
pros:
VMware is well established company and brand, well positioned in the market. 
It's a big american corporation, and gives the opportunity to a lot of people to work here, learn and progress in their careers. And not the traditional corporation, in general a more relaxed environment and people willing to help.

It has over the top benefits: 
- Gym membership
- Lunch card on top of your salary
- Insurance and dental insurance
- 40 hours a year for social service and match your donations to charities
- Team building activities
- 22 days of paid holidays a year, that you can take when you want.

They invest a lot in people's careers, there is always budget for training. 
You always get the tools you need to work (brand new laptop, 2 monitors, software licenses). 

VMware cares for their people. The Ireland office was closed and the people affected were relocated to the office in Barcelona, offered another job in Ireland or other office or got the indemnification. 
Another prove that they care about the people is higher management (senior VPs, directors, country managers, etc) visiting the office.

The growth of the office has been exponential, every few weeks there is people joining.
cons:
- There are periods when there is too much training going on. Specially because of VMware always innovating and developing new products that it might be overwhelming. 

- Change is constant.

- The holidays are subject to manager's approval. And there are periods when it's not possible to take holidays (end of quarter for example).

headline: I Appreciate the opportunity to work here
pros:
The pros,

Great connection with the products. 

Respected world wide brand and market leader.

Senior people in the business talk to you as an equal. They do not talk down to you. 

Salary to workload is amazing. Food cards with a substantial amount compared to other companies. 

Large amounts of onboarding training. 

 Start up feel which means you can somewhat push yourself to the front. 

People do get recognition. 

Coming from the outsourced world that obviously takes some adjustments. My role is manageable in terms of pay to work ratio. I remember working in some places where I was just a number and a quota. Here I am an individual where I am allowed to express myself and work in a manner that suits me. 

There is multiple groups in the office, force for good, sports and social and a POD hopefully overtime these groups will give employees a voice to shape this office how they want it to be. 

The company has already allowed us to be part of charitable causes. yesterday we refurbed a house for underprivileged children it gives you a great feeling that you can make a difference. Appreciate the position we are within a company like this that we can actually impact peoples lives.
cons:
Because of the start up feel it is a little hectic but we all knew that coming in. Sometimes coming into the bubble and big world of VMware you can lose a little bit of perspective. Sometimes you can forget that things can be worse because your not micromanaged to within an inch of your life. 
However a little more structure would help me from going on a tangent.

headline: Your manager determines your success at VMware
pros:
Your career journey/success at VMware will be defined by your manager.  Work/Life Balance, Upward Mobility, Cross Training or any career advancement is only existent if you have a manager and leadership team that will advocate on behalf of you and celebrate your accomplishments.  Advocating on behalf of yourself only goes so far when BU management has their favorites.

EPIC Values is a joke and no one is actually held accountable to them.  Vmware doesn't have a formal review process which is problematic because your manager is not obligated to communicate in a constructive way room for improvement/celebrate achievements.  

VMware has a LOT of work to do to actually give the representation they strive for outsiders to perceive.  Lots of senior leaders that only employ people brought over from their previous companies with aged experience which ultimately stunts innovation and creativity.  

Younger employees are perceived as inexperienced and lacking knowledge.  Someone has to either die or leave the company for you to be promoted.  Sad because there are actual employees that are invested in the organization but don't have to the opportunity to innovate and make a change.  And internal transfers are a joke - an external hire will be given the opportunity first, every time.  

So much for a "career journey" within the company.  This is contributed to the fact that 90% of the recruiters at VMware are contractors and are not invested in the company and could care less about the candidate recruiting experience, even with an employee referral.  


Pros: 
Unlimited PTO
Generous Paternity Leave
Professional Development Opportunities
Lots of company/family-friendly events for Palo Alto employees
Exposure to a variety of technologies
cons:
Lackluster and Mediocre Leadership
No Upward Mobility unless you're a management "favorite"
Terrible HR and Recruiting for External and Internal Candidates

Poor management who are young and have huge egos.  Business Development and EUC are the worst areas to work in.  You have no guidance and the office is so new to Barcelona nobody has a clue what they are doing.  It is complete chaos.  The products are niche and hard to sell and very very expensive so don't expect to start here on a great salary and have an easy ride because they make you work for your money, and if you don't hit targets they sack you.  Don't be fooled by the 4+ start reviews on Glassdoor, if you read these reviews are all based from employees in the USA, they treat everyone better there, after all, it's a US company.  All the fun, culture you read about is not happening in Barcelona, after all, you're in Spain and salaries suck!
Ireland was much better for salaries and culture but hey we know why we got relocated.

headline: Stay away for your own sanity
pros:
Good salary and benefits, good place
to make friends and pick up experience if you are just out of college
cons:
Where do I start? The most stressful work environment I have ever experienced. Micro-management / classroom environment, unsociable working hours, constant change of priorities, lack of trust from management. The second the working environment gets a bit calmer or normal, management come down on you like hyenas and shift priorities around again.

If you want to progress here, management still have the 1980’s mentality of being chained to your desk every night until 8-9pm (to the point of exhaustion). Doing the same job from home (i.e. more flexibility) doesn’t count. They want bodies on the ground. If you leave punctually you get that disapproving look of disgust as if you are the biggest slacker in the world.

Would rather be on unemployment benefits than go back here. If you want work/life balance and work in an environment where you feel empowered, trusted and made feel that you can do it your way and in your time, this is not the place for you. The closest thing to boot camp I have ever experienced.

To add insult to injury they feed you at Quarter End with fast food and junk food and expect you to be grateful for it, at the expense of your public holidays, weekends and late evenings of course.

Don’t let the benefits fool you, stay away from this place.

headline: Great place to work that values quality of life and family
pros: VMware is a big company but in many ways had a startup vibe. That was great because the resources and infrastructure of a big company were there, but it gave most people I worked with freedom to work on many projects, influence, move around, and contribute in many ways. Plus, many things moved faster than they might at other companies of the same size. Perks were really great including bonuses, events on the campus, opportunities, etc.
cons: The biggest con is the annual layoff. During most of the years I was there, we were growing like crazy, beating expectations, gaining in stock price, etc. It was always positive and upward. However, every single January, it was known that there would be a round of layoffs, even when all numbers were looking great as they almost always were. Management called it restructuring. But, over the years, some really good people were let go for no apparent reason. Then to add insult to injury, a week or two later, there would be a company quarterly meeting discussing how VMware was doing so well and is still hiring, but they had to make some changes. It always felt dishonest and the sympathy for those let go came across as disingenuous.

headline: Amazing Tech married with a Fantastic Culture
pros: The innovation and collaboration is outstanding. What's more the EPIC2 values that VMware espouses from the very top of the Leadership, are lived by the Leadership and cascade throughout the organisation. It's not a printed statement on a  wall, it's a genuine belief system. E=Execution, P=Passion. These two are evident always. I = Integrity and the professionalism of the people and the Leaders bears this out. Never have I experienced a place so hot on doing the right thing, even if it doesn't help you personally. Long-term thinking even though we have quarterly goals and usual target pressures, we understand what we're building isn't just 3 months worth. C=Customer and the customer focus especially to help fix their business problems rather than just sell products is maturing exponentially. Finally 2 = the second C - Community. A week a year to provide voluntary service to any community you choose, fully paid, and encouraged was and always will be a winner for me when I joined. We are all people, and very fortunate to work for a Company that gives back to help others benefit from our good fortune. Tech as a Force for Good really resonates.
cons: There's so much opportunity and energy that you need to gtake a conscious decision on what to focus on that develops you and VMware in equal measure. It's very easy to take on too much, but that's a choice you make rather than the Company piling it on
