This is the one large company that I have worked for where people live the values (in VMware's case these are EPIC2). VMware has a good balance of internal innovation and external acquisitions and our M&A and Senior Executives have done a great job of picking acquisition targets that fit culturally.
cons: The company is definitely hitting "big company" status manifested in many more people involved in decisions with no increased value add. Funding appears to go to big new initiatives that are either hit or miss. This approach has starved other areas going counter to the concept of allowing a thousand flowers to bloom. Several people site the trend to hire from outside rather than promote from within with examples of people leaving and being hired back in at a more senior level when they couldn't get the same promotion while at the company.

I made the same solving 30 support cases a  week from any company that could have as little as 25 devices, to traveling onsite to fortune 500 companies being the face of Airwatch. When it was review time, management threw every excuse in the book to not pay a cent more. They blamed the VMware acquisition and that the company didn't have the money. I spent 2 weeks in support, in 5 months in consulting and was being held at a salary less than 20k less than the average. Only stay if you have a high base salary, other wise, you will constantly be fighting an uphill battle. Younger kids fresh out of college are given basically whatever they ask for, so be sure to ask for high.

headline: Great Industry! Lacks in People Development
pros:
-This is an environment full of young professionals early in their career or approaching the mid-career phase. A great place to be if you're in one of those two stages in your career. 

-The mobile space is a very cool space to be in, and things move fast. AirWatch had very strong market share and was always winning awards and accolades. 

-Structurally solid, and VMware helped to accelerate that structure.

-The Christmas Party is awesome. 

-Sales often had different contests that often included some cool prizes (not sure if that still happens with VMware as the umbrella organization).
cons:
I was in sales so the majority of my feedback centers around the sales organization. 

-The sales organization is churn and burn. It's a catch 22, as they drive you to make XX number of calls per day, but ultimately they really only care about sales. Some salespeople have different methodologies and approaches for building their funnel. In 2015, making calls is only one of them. 

-AirWatch is all about territory. If you're in Mid-Market and you have a weaker or smaller territory geography or account wise, you can NOT prospect or sell to any accounts in Healthcare, Retail, Finance, Non-Profit, Government, organizations under 250 employees, organizations, over $500 Million in revenue, existing accounts over a year old, etc. etc. I understand that this is the model, but in some cases it creates a lose-lose situation for some people.

headline: Information Security Analyst
pros: Very young workplace, almost everyone is recent college grads. Very fun, and CEO John Marshall kept it super fun ever since startup mode to being bought out by VMware. Most employees will do work that's very complex and senior level  and have a chance to gain important skills. This is not a place to work at if you are skilled, rather it's a place where you work to develop skills. Once you have the skills, you leave AirWatch and double your salary somewhere else. Also, take advantage of the VMware name on your resume.
cons:
Internal employees are not valued and trained. The VMware acquisition was a cluster with poor management directives, especially on the DC Ops / Infosec side of the business. Information Security was seen as your typical 'check the checkbox' type of initiative, instead of a business initiative. Upper management treated infosec as a hinderance to business and more of a 'how do we make money off of this' model, instead of let's change our culture approach. Being underpaid was fine (as I was out to soak in skills) , but when your work isn't valued around by the business, you lose motivation quickly. 

There are lots of faults in every layer of management, but if executive management doesn't shift their current culture, the information security department will cease to exist. Maybe the culture will change once all the AirWatch executives are gone and replaced by VMware appointed executives. 

Skills that were worth $100-120k / year were being done by guys making less than $50k. No sane security professional will ever do the job at that rate ever again, especially considering the complexity of the projects.

headline: Products customers love

cons: There can be challenges at VMware in managing the trade-offs between maintaining existing product lines and investing in new product lines, sometimes causing changes in direction that can be frustrating and can cause teamwork issues.

cons: It's become a lot bigger and less growth opportunities available for new comers or even old-timers. It has the potential to become Oracle/IBM - that's a double-edge sword - and currently it's a bit uncertain if/when VMware does acquire the parent company, EMC.

headline: VMware has lost its way
pros: I would have said being surrounded by smart people with a purpose, lead by people with integrity, at a forward thinking company with a bright future - but I can't. Not anymore. That's what VMware used to be. Even the newest, most innovative group to come along in a long time - vCloud Air - has devolved into a political, back-stabbing mess populated with weak leadership that either already has or will soon drive off everybody with any talent and brains. And it seems this nightmare of a management team will even fire those that question any of this. Where are your EPIC values when they actually need to be tested VMware? In the trash, with all the other good things you ever did.
cons: If you think my Pros were Cons, wait till you hear the Cons. In summary, the leadership of the vCloud Air team specifically has somehow become convinced that they actually know what they are doing. No longer is there a sense of experimentation and risk taking, which attracted some of the brightest minds from across the company and the industry to sign up for the journey, but instead in their place are arrogance, ignorance, and politics. Arrogance is bread from the top down, with the "leaders" making arbitrary and damaging decisions while ignoring the informed counsel of the people WHO ACTUALLY DO THE JOB EVERYDAY. This leads to embarrassing displays of ignorance by the "leaders" in all hands presentations and customer meetings when false and/or falsified information is shared as the truth. And the politics of the place make it impossible for any of the smart folks who clearly know the information is untrue to call it out with their "leaders" for fear of retaliation in the form of public humiliation or firing. And they have good reason to be scared - retaliation is the new blood sport at VMware. Once there was a time when people could wake up and feel good about the challenges they faced everyday...now they wake up and dread every minute.

headline: Business Analyst
pros: The best part of working at VMware is the people. I truly have great coworkers. The work is really pretty interesting, and I have a pretty good amount of flexibility in doing the work that I want to do. The benefits are pretty good, too.
cons: No one in this department really gets promoted. When they do, they don't get raises. Only an annual salary review, and right now, our whole department is well underpaid against market salary. i recently got my annual raise - about $1,300, roughly 3%. Before that, i signed up for a parking program that has me park across the street because we don't have enough parking - I get $50/paycheck for that. That's $1,200/year. Sounds great, except that my company just told me that my parking across the street is worth about the same as the improvement I've shown since the beginning of employment (10 months).

headline: Unprofessional
pros:
VMware

AirWatch has an extremely young and inexperienced management team. There is no leadership or professionalism. They have no clue how to manage so they resort to micromanagement. We are constantly monitored for work hours, activities, etc. The work environment is hostile and unprofessional. It is apparent they do not believe in retaining talent. You cannot attract and retain the right talent by micromanaging!! I have never seen managers this unprofessional. There is a high turnover. Since people are quitting left and right, we are left with ridiculously heavy workload and they refuse to hire more employees to distribute the workload. Despite the heavy workload, Airwatch pays extremely low salaries that are far below the market. There are too many changes that are ineffective. We have something new everyday.
VMware needs to step in immediately to improve the work environment by replacing the management and set policies to make Airwatch a decent company.

If you have an issue it's almost like burden to talk to HR or any management as a matter of fact. No career growth with call center wages. The annual raise is an insulting joke! VMware needs to know! If you plan on having a long successful career with a company do not choose this one. Do yourself a favor! Don't invest your time because you will get zero recognition and pennies for a raise. cons: Sometimes the business decission made doesn't make sense. VMware is doing lot of catching up with things like AWS, Docker etc, so there is always a hurry to deliver, hence not always the right decision is taken.

headline: VMware and why I work there
pros: Everyone is on a mission to move the company forward
cons: I didn't get here soon enough

headline: Nice campus and pay | Not-so-interesting product roadmap | Some engineering teams do not code
pros:
- Pioneers of cloud software, it is THE company if you are a cloud computing enthusiast
- Pretty good campus
- Best place for systems engineering
- You'll get to learn lots of low level stuff
- Good pay
- Nice events - Friday bashes, VMware unplugged, RADIO(limited admission) & VMWorld
- Voice of VMware - A survey where you'll get to anonymously review your boss which is really great
cons:
- Be careful about the org you join, coz, some teams don't write significant code and all they do is things like bug triaging etc, which can be quite dangerous if you are a developer at heart
- Some managers tend to nag the employees and some don't even give a sh*t and just slack off, both are not good
- After couple of years, work can get routine and boring

headline: Management needs to work!
pros:
You can learn new technology , 
Virtualization Knowledge is huge gain.
Technical management is really good.
Quality of products.
cons:
Management only focuses on work,
Employee satisfaction is not looked upon.
Facility teams are not helping. Most of the times needs of employees are neglected.

headline: One of the best places to work in Silicon Valley
pros:
-Very smart employees
-Truly collaborative culture, you can approach nearly anyone and if you are competent, you will be welcomed with open arms
-In my group, caring and inclusive management team
-Excellent team work and camaraderie 
-People are happy here
-Work life balance is the best I have seen; don't get me wrong, we work hard, but people know when to unplug.
cons:
-As mentioned by others, the company's grown so fast, there seems to be some duplication and redundancy in work done across several organizations
-Mid-Level (Managers to Sr. Directors) could use training in how to encourage and develop employees.  Difference at VMW, this is recognized and discussed.  There are programs being kicked off to help managers learn how to be effective leaders.  I have not seen this in similar companies in my 20+years in the Valley.

headline: Poor
pros: Nothing much Nothing much at all.
cons: Not a good place to work. Employees are valued little and don't have much input on where they go within the company.

headline: If you are a new college grad, please do not join this company.
pros: You should first read my cons list. Maybe then the pros will make sense. The only pro that I can think of working at AirWatch is that i got to work at a terrible company so early on in my career that now i know what to look for when i am looking for jobs and have learnt not to make the same mistakes that i made over here.
cons:
Its a long list:
1. They will just about make anyone a team lead. For example: My manager was useless. A terrible listener. Will never try to understand a word of what i am saying and then just give their own opinions. After a while, when they would hear it from someone else, they would write a long scathing email about why i didnt inform them. 
2. Each team lead here has their own favorites and they are the ones who get good reviews and they can do nothing wrong. If your manager doesnt like you, you are screwed. Anything that you do will be reviewed 10,000 times and they will still find faults and raise questions about your performance. They will also compare you to their favorites and ask why cant you be like them. I am all for a healthy competition but everyone has their own working style so its unfair to compare people. This is the first thing a manager would know. But then they dont undergo any sort of training. HR doesnt even think it is worth spending time and money on training their people on how to be good managers.
3. The HR department here does not care what you are doing. I know someone who reached out to them because they were having problems with their lead and they didnt even reply to that person's email.
4. They expect the employees to be working 24x7 but will never show any appreciation for it.  People have stayed back and worked late in the night for projects so that they could meet deadlines. Instead of rewarding them or a single thank you, they were given more work. You have to sacrifice your personal life if you are working there.
5. No career opportunities. No promotions. You are just stunted in your career.

headline: VMware
pros: Great campus, gym.  Opportunity to help make the dominant virtualization product better.  Work with many brilliant people, some of whom have been there since the early days.
cons: Large conglomerate. Dozens of products makes it difficult for the company to maintain focus and set priorties.  Difficult for engineers to acquire sufficient hardware for large-scale testing.

headline: MTS3
pros: * Flexible work schedules
cons: * Poor upper management

headline: Fast-paced environment
pros: Fast paced-environment, great place to learn from new challenges. VMware is innovative at its core, company has vision and makes really cool, cutting edge products and solutions.
cons: Company is evolving, culture is evolving, some lack of clarity requiring ability to deal with ambiguity and adapting to changing landscape.

headline: Product Marketing Manager
pros: If you are with the right team you get ok bonuses and spot bonuses - otherwise it is pretty minimal. Benefits are good, beautiful campus, and onsite gym.
cons: You need to quit and come back to get a promotion, base salary is lower because they view they have a brand name, need to pay for usage of the gym.

headline: Inside Sales Representative
pros: Great benefits, smart colleagues, advancement from within.

headline: Senior Engagement Manager
pros: beautiful campus set in Palo Alto, and nice cafeteria.
cons: CFO manages the business via lay-offs and re-hiring versus building a sustainable business model #sadwaytomanage.

headline: A great place to work
pros: VMware Bulgaria is one of the top choices in the country for career development and innovation. It offers a variety of positions and caters to people's aspirations for growth. The pay is competitive and the benefits are great. Depending on your team, you have Agile processes and choose your own tasks. Amazing work/life balance that allows you to stay only a few hours if you can complete your tasks fast, or stay overtime if you are swarmed. You can work from home, working hours are floating (some people come at 14:00h, some leave at 15:00h etc.).
cons: Depending on the team that you join, you might face horrible processes (not all teams have Scrum), you might be pigeonholed into fixing bugs or do tasks that are not to your liking. So there is a bit of RNG and you hope for the best.

headline: VMware is a 'Rock Star' company!
pros: Great teamwork also across countries/regions, very competent colleagues, numerous career advancements, clear company strategy.
cons: Organisational changes may occur a bit too often, as this is still a company growing. This can sometime give some noise.

headline: Best place to work ever
pros: It's so awesome working here, hours are great, management cares about their employees
cons: None that I can think of

headline: Established company in the belt-tightening phase
author_position: Member of Technical Staff Software Engineer
pros:
Work-from-home
Work life balance and PTO depends entirely on your manager.
Access to lots of training
Turtles
cons:
Average salary, average benefits.
50-60 hours a week, weekends and holidays when projects are due.
~1-2% yearly raises, no promotions, no equity after hiring.
Laysoffs every 9-12 months focusing on highest salaried employees.
Constant management churn.  Expect a new manager and VP every year and a new reporting group every other year.
Training must be done on your own time.

headline: Client Executive Experience
pros:
VMware is truly a leader in our industry with a great breadth of tools & capabilities.
There is real opportunity in EUC, NSX, & VSAN.
The benefits are good, and the pay is above average.  You can make a lot of money in the right situation.
cons:
My entire management team is stuck in Salesforce 24 hours a day.  There is very little organization and a clear lack of leadership.  It's evident that mid-level management is being told what to do rather than helping contribute to our success.

VMware is struggling with becoming a matrixed sales organization, and the technical sales organization is an absolute joke across the board.  You WILL be on your own, and expected to sink or swim.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Good people, intelligent, motivated, sincere. Great collaborative culture where you can approach almost anyone in the company. Innovation is encouraged and people and groups are empowered to do so. Schedule flexibility and good work life balance, but you'll still work very hard (and enjoy it).
cons: The empowerment of people and groups to innovate leads to duplication of effort sometimes. Some people have been in the company too long for their own good and are outdated. The company has traditionally been one level removed from hardware, and it is making the efforts to change to be more lean and agile, but change is painful and changing people's mindsets takes time. For anything other than AirWatch, you will need to be in Palo Alto. The core of VMware does not do well with a distributed environment. The San Francisco office shrunk as VMware gave up the better half of the floor.

headline: EPIC!

They even sent $30,000 in free software to a local non-profit because I simply asked to help them - sincere, meaningful impact.  Palo Alto campus is outstanding, with a great vibe and culture! headline: Great place to work

headline: I love working at VMware!
pros: It's great to work at a company with a range of products and services that are doing well. I work with a lot of very smart people--but all very different. The management here really cares about their employees. I appreciate that when they need to make benefit changes, they survey the employees for our priorities. There are a wide range of health benefits, a great gym with classes, a beautiful campus with walking trails, decent cafeterias. Management embraces diversity, too, and is really making an effort to embrace change.
cons: A worldwide workforce can mean that someone has to meet at odd hours. I accept that occasionally I have evening meetings.

headline: Staff Systems Engineer
author_position: Staff Systems Engineer ­ VCloud Air Specialist
pros: Great vision and leadership.  VMware continues to innovate even has they become a very large corporation, where most large corporations acquire companies vs innovating.
cons: The innovation can take a long time.  It also seems some business units don't communicate with each other.  I call these tier 1 company problems.  You find this to be true at any other company...

headline: Great Colleagues, Poor Management
pros:
Fantastic place to gain experience as companies love VMware on your CV. You will meet a lot of like minded people who are very knowledgeable in what they do.

The people that work in VMware make VMware the company that it is. Unfortunately it seems that for the past 6 months VMware has had an overflow of employees who are leaving the company.

This in turn has put a great amount of pressure on the people who are currently still with VMware.
cons:
Management in VMware is one of the worst I have ever experienced. Promises are made but very rarely kept.

Pressure is piled on to perform and get results that are ridiculous and impossible to achieve. 

Company (Management) needs to focus on weeding out the managers that are the reason for all of the senior engineers leaving the company.

Currently VMware is not offering a competitive wage. A similar job in other tech companies can easily result in a 100% increase in wage.

This is another reason why people are leaving VMware. If the management stopped focusing on hiring WPP's (who definitely deserve the chance to get back to work) and put more effort into keeping people with experience the company would have a much better foot to stand on compared to other tech companies.

Also, in relation to the wages it is advisable to pay the industry standard rate instead of trying to get by with measly pay increases of 2-3%

cons:

-There are growing pains as AirWatch transitions to being "AirWatch by VMware," it is difficult for an entire company to shift its strategy from getting customers by jamming features into the product to creating a quality product that works well. 
-Internally, there are still significant gaps in communication between teams. I waste a lot of time explaining the same things over and over again...where to find a document, what the online help is, etc...

headline: Would recommend working here - but obvious areas for growth exist

headline: A great place to challenge yourself where initiative is rewarded
pros: A culture that cares about employees, shareholders, customers and our communities.  VMware rewards performance and has attractive benefits.   We are encouraged to grow our capabilities and provided opportunities for career growth.   Whether working with Habitat for Humanity,  building artificial hands or the next great software product, VMware encourages and supports our efforts.
cons: As VMware grows into a much larger organization,  some additional bureaucracy is to be expected.   Very much a quarterly driven sales organization,  would prefer a longer measurement cycle of a year, but is probably unrealistic for a public company in the U.S.

headline: Best company I have worked for....

I have been with 3 other tech vendors of similar size to VMware. After 4 years VMware is still the best place have worked.
I bench mark regularly  and compensation/benefits are generally excellent.
VMware is generally ok with home working and relocation.
Senior management team is mature - I haven't seen pettiness or empire building that I have seen in other companies.
First place I have worked where the HR organization is professional and innovative.
Given a lot scope in my current role.
VMware's continued growth and breadth of products keeps things interesting and means there are lots of opportunities.
cons: VMware is now a big company so the normal bureaucracy that comes with that has crept in. But although decision making can be slow at times - it is better than other places I have worked.

headline: VMware - From the Field!
pros: People at VMware are just plain NICE!  There is a culture of understanding here that everyone has lives outside of work and that it is equally important that we take care of our families as well as our business.
cons: The only "Con" of working at VMware is that being a software company, there is a lot of innovation on the products that means as an Account Executive you have to put in the extra time for training to keep up with all of the features of the solutions in order to be able to communicate the outcomes the features drive to the customers.

headline: Systems Engineer

headline: Loving It

cons: Every company has it's minor irks and irritations, and VMware is no different.  Sure, there are things that I would do differently if I ran the company, but they're immaterial in the grand scheme of things.

headline: Great Community inside a Company
pros: Great company; great people; great values.  Strong sense of community.  The company walks the talk when it comes to its EPIC2 values and especially on giving back.  Awesome programs and perks for employees.  Stunning green campus in Palo Alto.
cons: Rapid growth and business transformation means that this is not a good place for people who like  to coast or sunset.

headline: An awesome career choice
pros: The constant stimulation and challenges to grow and learn at a near constant rate is simply fabulous.  This is a company that does not fit the "daily 9 to 5" stereotype.  Every assignment is a new challenge.
cons: There are often times that leave me with little communication within the company.  There is a high rate of travel which isn't the bad part, it's the difficulty keeping in touch with peers due to the travel.

headline: Field Sales Rep - Great Company

headline: Sr. MTS

headline: Inside Sales Representative
pros: Company has some good products in a highly commoditized and competitive industry.
cons: They are increasingly hiring less skilled people to cut costs, which is directly impacting the companies ability to sell the new products lines.  Sales teams have no measurable goals other than the number, and the company added an MBO structure that essentially cuts your income in half.  Does not offer competitive benefits for the industry.

headline: VMware - A great company to work for and continuing to get better
pros:
VMware's commitment through the VMware Foundation to give back to the community through donation matches, programs to provide time off work with charitable organizations, and their ongoing presence and efforts at all our company events to encourage employees to take advantage of all these offerings is really special.

Leadership up and down the ladder are very interested in providing the best opportunities possible for the employees and they have been on an active drive for many years now to continue to evaluate and improve.  Truly fantastic and something I haven't seen in such force before.

Opportunities for personal career growth through many different training options, established programs, and internal opportunities to move around and work in many different areas.

I can't stress enough the opportunities for growth, promotion, etc.  There are so many ways to learn about our products, interesting new projects in technical depth, obtain training on job and career skills, contribute back to the community(!), and opportunities to be visible and acknowledged for your contributions at many different leadership levels.

Benefits are rock solid.

Hard (and good) work is acknowledged.

Flexibility in the schedule is superb so long as it's not abused.

Coworkers are smart and driven!

Innovation is a key component to VMware's culture and is highly, highly encouraged and many opportunities to demonstrate innovative ideas and even foster them into being are available.
cons: I'm not sure if this is common industry wide, but the frequency of reorganizations seems very excessive.

headline: It's a great place to work where employees are valued
pros: Some of the brightest people in the world work at VMware. It's a real think-tank. The technology and people are what drive us forward. I feel honored to work among such awesome people.
cons: Make sure that you spend time on the salary discussion, because even though the raises at VMware are OK, the best raise you will ever get is in your salary negotiations before you start. I have had a couple of raises, one of them is stellar, and one was mediocre.

headline: great past, uncertain future, high potential
pros: Self-starter culture, plenty of day to day empowerment, huge customer base with very positive relationship, above average salary and benefits, lots of believers.
cons: Culture- some areas approach things like sales and R&D in the same virtualization-focused mindset that worked 6 years ago, but the current market needs a more solution-focused approach, rapid iteration and strong link to business value. This mindset is often found in the people that have been here the longest and have had great success in the past, putting them in positions of influence, making it tough to shift.

headline: Consultant

cons: The strategy within Professional Services requires an unhealthy emphasis on billing utilization to the detriment of customer satisfaction.

headline: Company at risk towards mediocrity
pros: Still has many of the early superstar engineers and manages to attract NCG recruits from top universities to keep the talent level relatively good.

headline: As many perks as uncooperative workers
pros: Great benefits, exciting technologies to work with. Being a VMware subsidiary should eventually pay off.
cons: You will see mistakes all the time, company rarely learns from them. No follow up on career advancement touted. Very uneven distribution of work load. Some work 6-7h days and others 70h weeks. Quality of products and services never ceases to suffer from approximations and mistakes, a contagious "yes we do everything" mindset and mindless footprint expansion (illusion of extra $). Severely uncooperative individuals and poor communication/coordination undermine overall capacity to execute, as confirmed in analyst reports. Current culture makes everyone look and feel awful with constant war rooms to meet overdue and broken solutions, which are a natural result of dedicating no more attention to any system than 30min meetings.

headline: Decline in culture let by management
pros: Nice campus (Palo Alto, Bangalore), interesting visitor programs (speakers, musicians), good bonus/stock (for some), generally nice co-workers and most are smart/capable (though not all "good" co-workers).  The VMware foundation encourages community giving. It's fantastic.
cons:
Recent years, despite financial success/growth, have been challenging at VMW. There are various reasons. To me there are three top level factors in the company's decline from a top place to work: (1) "Stock advocates" putting pressure on EMC to sell of VMW to "unlock" share holder value.  (2) Aggressive and (seeming) directionless drive to develop the next growth technology. (3) Infiltration of "Good Old Boy" management. 

The affects of each of factors are subtle and significant by themselves, but very impactful together.  (1) Forces cost control and places a premium on a "need to move quickly" to hold off the advocates.  This drives poor planing, staffing (no hiring in certain places, forced multi time zone teams), and a shotgun approach to product development,  leading to poor execution.  This puts tremendous pressure on the employees, making it a less desirable place to work, proven by high sr mgmt and engineering turn over in the last year.  Replacement mgmt comes brings outside cultures, which can be good depending on where it comes from, but turned out bad for VMW (good old boys and empire builders that were laid off from "successful companies").

headline: A good place to work for the right individual...but some risk over the next year.
pros: VMware has a very collegial and entrepreneurial culture.  Pay and benefits are good with a generous charitable giving  match of up to $3,140  per year.  You also get to work at the forefront of private cloud transformation of some of the world's biggest companies.
cons: Change is constant which isn't necessarily bad if you can adapt or if you thrive in ambiguous environments.  However, too much change can and does inhibit execution.  VMware is still going through a sales transformation from selling server virtualization to a full software suite for building and managing private clouds.  The EMC Federation is also gearing up to drive more complicated sales engagements however, the end game is unclear.  There is risk as to what is going to happen with VMware.  It may be spun out or sold to another company.  It may get more fully consumed into EMC or it may stay status quo if the Federation can positively impact the velocity of cloud sales growth.

headline: Place is starting to show more room for career growth
pros:
with the acquisition the company is starting to show that there is a ladder and room for career growth. a person can look at this company and say I can see myself working there for 5 or 10 years or something before it was just a good place to start your career but nows its gone on to being more. 

VMWare benefits are really starting to kick in and so far its been a good thing. 

work/life balance is somewhat okay

teammates are generally great to work with esp. our india counter parts. flexible work schedule is good. perks like hackathon, six flags, braves games, and christmas party awesome. if you want to switch to another position your teammates will generally encourage you to do so. such as QA to PM or QA to TAM or such. moving within company show we have big spots for career growth. I can join as QA and in a few years switch to PM or Dev position and get that experience. we have a lot of internationals who travel to home and bring back some sweets so get ready for delicious foreign sweets.  generally speaking i'm happy joining this company and can see myself here a long time.
cons:
your experience will def. depend on your manager. certain managers micro-manage the heck out of their teams esp. those who don't really follow the modules well, but drift in and out which is the worst because they will miscommunicate something and all hell breaks loose. not all managers are like this. some do a decent job of keeping up with things but the ones who drift in and out are the worst. so your time will def. depend on your manager. 

the way the titles were handled were a mess because some of the veteran employees had to do timesheets and limited vacation time and such while other freshers had no time sheet and unlimited vacation. they overload you with things to do and pester the whole team about it later. i'm really starting to see why the turnover rate in QA was so high. 

honestly your experience will highly depend on the manager you get and your teammates. people here are friendly for the most part so you wont have much of problems with teammates but you may have problems with manager.

headline: High turnover rate for a reason
pros: VMWare is becoming more involved and hopefully changing the culture at Air Watch.
cons:
The entire business model of AirWatch is finding the cheapest possible labor.  They usually hire recent graduates who have no idea how underpaid they are.  Most of the people who leave usually find jobs that double their former salary at AirWatch.  They exploit smart people who join Air Watch from their Wandering Wifi division by paying them extremely low wages and use their lack of education as an excuse.
There is a reason why the moment the most talented people are leaving Air Watch at an alarming rate.
Don't be fooled when Air Watch claims to be one of the best companies or best paying companies.  That stat is all VMWare, Air Watch is nothing like VMWare...the only thing they share is a name.

headline: Disappointing
pros: At the most basic level VMware really takes care of its employees. There are relatively few companies that can match what VMware offers with respect to standard and non-standard benefits. If you're good at what you do and are in a high-demand area you'll be rewarded with a very generous salary, bonus, and stock grants. The health benefits, vacation time, and access to high quality training, among other benefits, are truly top notch.  There are little things too, like assistance with medical costs for those having trouble conceiving. I love VMware for this type of stuff. Additionally, the Palo Alto campus where I'm located is truly in a league of its own. Anything you could possibly want, it's here. You want a top notch gym. It's here. Multiple cafeterias with various food types? It's here. On site dental and medical care? It's here. Pinball machines? Ping pong tables? Volley ball courts? All here. The list could go on. Pretty incredible.
cons:
Unfortunately despite all of the Pros I listed, the cons outweigh them for me, unfortunately.

I'll be leaving within the month.

In a nutshell there is a HUGE management problem at VMware. I've only started in the past 6 months so I came in with what I like to think is a fresh perspective. If you can, scroll through the past Glassdoor reviews and look for one titled “Looking back, VMware has some major problems” from November, 2014. It turned out to be very, very prescient for me. I remember reading it before I started and thinking, "well, that's interesting." It hits the nail so squarely on the head it's a bit eery. 

To summarize and add my own color to that review: There is a huge disconnect between the various levels of management at VMware and what you get from one high-level VP, may not match what the Director says, which may not match what your manager says. 

Very regularly I will have a Sr Director or VP bypass my own leader (a Director) and give me completely different priorities and instructions. You end up in a situation where you're damned if you do and damned if you don't. And, just like in the movie Office Space, you find yourself telling the same thing to 3 different managers who are asking you to fill out your TPS reports correctly. I'm an engineering manager, my job is mostly spent sorting out politics and not leading a team of capable engineers.

Ultimately the problem really affects the individual contributors, the folks that really make it happen, who are left to sort out the mess. Not surprisingly, folks get and frustrated and leave. The turn-over rate, at least in my group, is depressing. 

It's impossible to retain the top talent that VMware desperately needs to stay relevant as the technology they've built the whole business on is quickly changing (containers, Amazon, etc). There are two main camps (maybe three) of folks who seem to stick it out:

(A) Those who are afraid to go outside of VMware because this is all they've become jaded and complacent. This has become all they know. The tell tale sign is you see them shopping online all day, reading facebook, etc.

(B) Those on visas or something similar from India/China/etc who don't have an easy path to moving to somewhere else or are only aware of this sort of big company culture. 

(C) The third camp of folks is the highest level executives, who are quite polished as you'd expect, they stick it out because they're not really exposed to what's going on at the lower levels and are likely oblivious, or don't really care. This is just a notch in their belt before they move on to their next executive position.

At the end of the day you're left with people who feel stuck (and are driven like rented mules to make up for the lack of quality engineers, eg working harder versus smarter) as they watch brief gusts of fresh air come by (new, smart, intelligent engineers) that quickly evacuate as soon as they get a hold of how things operate. 

It's a shame really. :-( I was so excited to be at VMware but it's time to go after only 6 months.

headline: I love coming to work every day! :)
pros:
-Incredibly kind, smart, fast-paced people. Everyone's contributions are really valued and surprisingly flat organization given its size.
-Great work/life balance and ability to work remote; VMware employees get to personally make good use of its virtualization technology to access any of their workspaces, anytime, anywhere.
-The Palo Alto campus is probably one of the prettiest in the Valley, with great subsidized healthy food and lovely, environmentally-conscious architecture and greenery.
-Lots of very exciting products, new releases, cross-functional marketing campaigns, and competitive spirit.
-Love the culture and leadership, who really emphasize the importance of and reward you for giving back to charitable causes--truly a compassionate community.
-Incredible perks, including unlimited vacation + 5 PTO days for volunteer work, an abundance of free healthy snacks, very generous policies when it comes to ordering office supplies and getting learning resources for yourself, Friday bashes with free food/live music/drinks (both alcoholic & not), hackathons/bootcamps, tons of transportation options including shuttles, and generous health benefits + 401k matching.

In a nutshell: It really is the epitome of a company that works and thinks like a startup but delivers like an enterprise.
cons: There are definitely some communication humps to get over as well as some internal operational challenges when it comes to alignment and reporting.

A lot of process redundancy with resistance to change.  Career advancement may lead to "pay reset" (in my case paying less money!).  Benefits are being clamped down on to reduce costs (i.e., elimination of internet reimbursement, increasingly lowering cell phone plan reimbursement amounts, etc). Much of that has to do with management bloat, red tape, resistance to change, resistance to address inefficient processes & procedures.

Incredibly powerful vision - the promise of the software defined data center is powerful and if pitched correctly at the right level can pique executive interest and lead to increased sales
People - there are absolutely fantastic people here: smart, driven, kind and genuinely good people
cons:
work-life balance is difficult - if you don't set boundaries and have a manager who understands balance you could be working 70-80 hour weeks and burn out. I am trying to avoid burnout due to all the pros above
VMware wants to be the next IBM or HP, with fulfilling services lead transformation projects, however the current professional services organization and talent is not even close to where it needs to be. Most are still left over services people who can't sell, they write SoWs
Quotas jump astronomically year over year - mine was increased over 50%. So even reaching presidents club the year prior, you feel a bit punished for working so hard

headline: A one year long training ground

- No clear designation of job titles. You might be hired for a specific position; simply to have your title changed by the company to something else after you join. 
- Zero support for employee development.
- Managers do not work with each others. Each manager has his/her own political agenda. 
- Lower than average salary
- Crude products. Managers continue to emphasize qualities, but only verbally.
- The company always tout about the Trade Floor as an open and collaborative environment. Google trade floor and AirWatch. Anyone will tell you that you work in a factory farm, sweat shop or something. I see it as a major distraction. How do you expect people to work when others come over every 5 min.  If it is such a great environment, why isn't the CEO working on the Trad Floor?

headline: Great culture, but overall as a company, not so great...
pros:
- benefits
- culture (EPIC2)
- company events (beer bashes, guest speakers, guest artists, off the grid, etc.)
- gorgeous campus
- great and intelligent people
- disruptive technology
cons:
In terms of the company, there is NO professional development and growth what so ever. It is promoted, but never actioned. From my experience, I have applied for several internal positions, but was treated like an external individual trying to get into the company. No common courtesy for internal employees with the exception of one time. If VMware does not act quickly, employee retention will be very minimal. There is already high turnover in my department because of this.

As for my department, it is not aligned with VMware's EPIC2 values. No transparency, no work/life balance, no integrity, no sense of community, no trust and no flexibility. For the amount of stress and long hours that came with the role, the pay should compensate for that. The commute is tough so I wish there were more opportunities to work remote than once a month.

headline: Small organization with no work culture.
pros:
- Free Cabs
- Free evening snacks (for those who love oil bath)
- Compensation at par with market standards
cons:
- Managers and HRs send mails to write good reviews in glassdoor. If I had an option to upload pics, I would have shared the screenshot of the emails send by these managers
- This is not a US product based company. It is a Kannada product based company. People talk to each other in Kannada all the time.
- I have been in 3 organizations before this, and this has been the worst. I have never seen any organization with such pathetic, low class, uncultured, manner-less leads and managers in my entire life. Scolding and shouting at junior resources in a common scene here
- Support Engineers have taken up QA lead positions here and have spoiled the work environment entirely in QA. Nonetheless the QA team itself is useless so it doesn't matter much.
- I was sent onsite for 10 days (which is the max no. of days for any person in Airwatch) and had a terrible time reimbursing the expenses.
- HR team is entirely missing from the organization. They live in their own little world and don't even bother about what is going on within their company. They are not aware about HR policies, they don't encourage or do any employee engagement activities. Sending out - New Joiner, Lost & Found mails etc. is the only thing they know.
- VMWare leave policies was integrated way back with Airwatch, still the managers and HRs say that they have not been implemented yet. They force the employees to follow the old policies because it suits them.
- Coming to our Dev team, well, technology wise it is good. There something new to learn if you are in the right team. But the internal politics spoils the fun. And now a days the offshore team does only bug fixing and other support work
- Unhygienic and dirty cafeteria and washrooms.

Please search Airwatch in Google Play Store and see the review with your own eyes. You will get a clear picture about how much this product actually SUCKS !

Please don't join this company by looking at 3+ star reviews. These have been posted by the HRs using multiple fake IDs. They send out mails on a regular basis asking their employees to do the same. I too joined this company seeing the positive reviews, but later on realized that this was the worst decision of my life.

headline: Great if you're in Palo Alto, sucks if you're in Austin
pros: Good tech, smart people, great health insurance
cons: No one in sales is making real money.  $4million annual quotas and people aren't even making six figures?  Not even 1% of sales??  That's just insulting.  Micromanagement straight from the Dell playbook - go figure, since most of their Austin managers and employees were poached from Dell.  Success (which means pay) depends mostly on who you suck up to in management and therefore what territory they give you.  Work/life balance and vacation policy are a joke.  Frat bro / sorority sister culture.  Office is in the middle of 360, so you're going to be stuck in traffic an hour a day unless you live in Westlake or downtown.  Clearly a haves and have-nots comparison between Austin and the Palo Alto campus.  They even started whittling down our choice of snacks from the break room, meanwhile Palo Alto has a made-to-order cafeteria with over 10 kinds of food.  No onsite cafeteria, and the food trucks sometimes just don't show up.

headline: Best experience in my career
pros:
Joined VMware after more than 20 years' of experience at a number of companies.  Having worked elsewhere, the HR Happy Song here at VMware sounded familiar--how employees were our greatest resource etc.

. . . except here @ VMW they really seem to mean it.  The transparency and level of communication from senior management is amazing.
cons: Advancement can be limited if not located in Palo Alto.  Can have a short-term numbers focus at the expense of long-term success.  Can be bipolar with budgets--a lot of emergency cost-cutting, countered with bouts of "hurry up and spend."

headline: Constantly evolving, sometimes frustrating, but ultimately awesome
pros: The best thing about VMware in my opinion is that they are willing to invest in their employees. Rather than force you to hop jobs as is done so frequently in the Valley, VMware is much more willing to promote from within. There is a strong base of VMware "lifers" who are the pillars of the internal management team, and there is mentorship and success to be had if you have the right attitude. Work/life balance is excellent.
cons: VMware has had a little too much "evolving" going on lately. Large scale and poorly planned shakeups have left some disillusioned or feeling rudderless. While this is hopefully all behind us, having seen major reorganizations happen several times in my tenure I do worry that it may continue.

headline: Overall, a great company with innovative products.  However certain departments are understaffed and overworked.
pros: Great benefits, and great overall culture.   Ongoing training and career advancement opportunities.  Very flexible vacation policy (with management approval).  Compensation is comparable with industry standard.  Very fast pace, never a dull moment.
cons: As in most org's, there are "clique's", and if you are not savvy enough to develop those relationships, you will be overlooked regardless of your performance.  Support staff was insufficient to meet demands of the business, therefore causing staff to be overworked.  Sales compensation plan very difficult to understand, and changes at least twice a year.

headline: A company that leads in technology despite mediocre-to-poor marketing communications.
pros: Great technologies, and very smart people at the upper levels -- Sr. Director and above.
cons: I can't speak to the technology side -- my impression is VMware is probably a great company to work for on that side of the house.. But the cultural values in marketing communications, where I spent my days, are quantity and speed vs. quality of work and smart thinking. VMware seems to have a knack for hiring marketing people at the manager and director level who wouldn't know quality design or writing if they tripped over it -- which they don't often do, and sadly, they don't really care. Suggestions that would improve someone's pet project or initiative are routinely ignored.  People get favored and promoted owing to political skills more than anything else. Ultimately, most of the really talented people I knew in VMware marketing ended up leaving.

headline: In general, VMware rocks. I am proud to say I work for this company.
pros:
* Fully-stocked break room full of free drinks and snacks. Bagel/breakfast taco Wednesday is awesome.
* Smart group of techies that are able to solve almost any challenge with ease.
* Management sees the work done and actively gives "attaboys".
* Communication through any customer issues are done to the entire org, which is nice.
* We all work as a team for a common goal - success to the customer.
* We offer products to better our customers worlds, as well as our own.
* Direct access to VMware developers can help make VMware customers have an optimal experience with the code before it hits "GA" status. We are our own beta testers of service provider code.
* Again, we all believe in the common goal. For ourselves and our customers.
cons: * New solutions come through the pipe so quick that sometimes issues happen during deployment to production environments. This impacts customers. See "Advice to Management".

headline: Pathetic Company ! Wasted 2 precious years of mine in AirWatch.
pros:
1. Free AC cabs.
2. No work in QA.
3. TT, Carrom and Chess for recreation - 5pm to 6pm.
4. No variable pay. Initial compensation is good.
cons:
1. No onsite opportunities. Honestly, the on-site opportunities here are zero. There are a few developers who get once in a life time opportunity to travel to Atlanta - for 10 days.
2. Hygiene level is equivalent to that of a local railway station. Cafeteria stinks, the toilets are in very bad condition. The office carpets and desks are cleaned one in 2 weeks or so.
3.Food quality is pathetic. There is one North Indian and one South Indian vendor, both don't offer varieties. There is a juice counter which is worse than the lunch vendors. Omelettes prepared 2 days back are served along with the sandwiches.
4. Gives you a back to school feeling. You cannot raise your voice if u feel anything around you is wrong. The Dev managers are dictators and most of the QA managers are trying to be like him apart from a few. You cannot play TT or other recreation games before 5 p.m.
5. No work life balance for Dev. You are on call 24x7.
6. Hikes are delayed without any prior intimation.
7. The leave policies are integrated with VMWare's policy. Still the managers don't allow you to take leaves.
8. No work from home policy.
9. Regional language is used for communication within the office. People from other states - Beware !
10. There is no work in QA, still they are hiring people like sheep and cattle.
11. In house WiFi goes down frequently. This gives you a govt. bank like feeling, and creates a very good impression among the onshore team who are convinced that we are a backward country.
12. No room for innovation.
13. I have heard there is an HR team somewhere inside a secret room. But unfortunately, I haven't met them so far.  Strange.

headline: Not for the faint hearted
pros: Some good products, good clear strategy and vision for a software defined enterprise. Lots of competent long-serving technical consultants are the backbone of the sales organisation.
cons: As a company VMware are having to transition from being a dominant player in a clear area (compute vitualization) to a contender across the Cloud Infrstructure space. As such there are sudden shifts in emphasis and organisational changes. This has meant pressure on positions and people and they do not always handle it well. In the UK there seems to be a high attrition rate amongst sales and sales management. It looks as though the senior managers are immune so there is a lot of churn lower down. The turnover in sales people was high due to a number of factors including unacheiveable targets, 6 month plans, random redundancies and ineffectual managers. This has now become a pretty cut-throat organisation and not for the faint hearted!

headline: Typical call center, fabled "VMware Culture™" is MIA
pros:
-On the surface, it's above average pay for doing tech support, but the breadth of knowledge required to be effective makes the bottom salary for this position seem like peanuts.  If you don't think you're worth 70k, your skills probably aren't up to snuff to thrive in the job.  
-RSUs are nice, but take forever to vest
-Set schedule, except for surprise mandatory overtime on weekends for which you may only get 3 or 4 days notice.
cons:
Over the last 6-10 months, there's been a hiring frenzy, a hiring freeze, and a mass exodus of some of the top performers.  Management decided not to backfill before the end of the year (likely to come in under budget and line some upper management pants with a fat bonus), increasing workload on those that remained.  Re-implemented weekends for everyone.  Started taking away perks.  Implemented some insane procedural policies and changes to the ticketing system I would be embarrassed to call a pre beta against the better judgement of virtually everyone that has to actually use it.  Announced a reorg saying that there were no plans to move positions to other countries.  Subsequently culled part of the herd including a manager while saying it was ok, because we're filling seats in the other countries.  Management just puts on a happy face while the rest of us facepalm.

These events are the exact opposite of what they obviously oversold when talking about this mythical VMware Culture™ that possibly at one time existed, but never really witnessed.

headline: Mobile Device Management in the South East region
pros:
The People: a young and generally motivated workforce helps to drive innovation and keep day to day life interesting.

The Location: Convenient location in walking distance of a major light rail station, with company subsidization, as well as a prime spot at the intersection of two large roads helps keep the job in reach for employees living around Atlanta.

Change in Ownership: VMWare's purchase appears to have had largely positive affects with regards to benefits and employee pay. Additionally, the change has moved the company out of start-up mode, so instead of product-product-product, there is a shift going on towards quality that benefits employee well being.
cons:
The Management: The company leadership at the AirWatch level is still driven by a sales-first principle that keeps R&D from ever getting to work towards product quality. Pushing to change from the start-up 'land grab' thought process where market share is everything to a more established company's concern for providing quality to its customers will make employees, investors, and customers happy. We've got the market share, now lets make the product work right.

Support Organization Training: R&D is directly involved in day-to-day support, because the PSO/Support organization does not receive adequate training in the product prior to being thrown to the wolves. QA and Development resources are dedicated to what is essentially tier 4 support for entire product release cycles (which damages the quality of new code going out the door due to resource squeeze) on a per team basis, and there is a real sense that the R&D team is the end-all, be-all of where the buck stops for any issue. Given the nature of this belief in the company, support team members are not incentive to do any critical thinking or problem solving, as the solution to most customer issues is to push a ticket to the R&D team for support, after which they can offload responsibility for the issue. Better training for the support team would prevent the issue with R&D resource allocation (making the product better, making support less time consuming, etc.), and help provide better support to the customer.

Hiring Policies: Internally, there appears to be a feeling that quality can be driven by adding additional BA/PM team members to a scrum/product group, while having a sometimes 3:1 or 4:1 developer to QA ratio. QA is asked to certify releases with little to no real time to test the product fully, which results in quality loss (and employee frustration). Instead of trying to drive quality through development/PM, try to build teams with a more reasonable ratio (2:1 Dev to QA?), so that real quality can be a focus instead of a pipe-dream.

headline: Not so fun place to work

Technology technology technology....you get to work on the latest and niche technology.
You have a young and dynamic team members working along with you who love exploring new technologies.
People who are passionate about IT and MDM have a great scope here.
cons:
A specific group of people talk in their native language and i can hardly get what they are discussing. 
And i get a feeling that the better chunk of work is given to the same group as well by the lead(who by the way belongs to the same set).
The HR team is of no use here. All the decisions are taken by only 2 people, both being spearheads of technology group.
The policies are not so great as far as work life balance is concerned. The work from home concept exists but only to a privileged few. They do encourage people in participating in Hackathons and patent filing and white paper submissions, but its made as a part of your goals rather than a self/team innovation and very much becomes a criteria for your hikes and promotion.
They look for a person to be in office and work 24hrs just be given an average rating.
After VMware acquisition, thought the policies would be changed, but there were no significant changes to benefit us. All we Indian employees get is to reimburse gym bills and got an upgrade on the referral bonus, no leave policy change(just 15 days of leaves), no so called VMWare employee perks showcased,nor did anyone come and let us know what policies are coming into effect.
If someone is merely passionate about work and who is looking for research kind of roles without expecting any employee benefits, this is the right place for you to be the managers fav.

headline: Company tries to do good for employees, but too many/daily offshore early AM or late PM work sessions
pros: In Palo Alto: Beautiful campus, tons of online training options, different R&D programs for submitting creative ideas, TALK programs with outside speakers, programs inviting celebrities for on campus performance, VMwomen/diversity initiatives, food trucks a few times a year, awesome halloween party for family with young children, beer bash.
cons: Budget cuts year over year.  Moved people to lower cost countries that drives too many daily offshore early AM and late PM work sessions or handover sessions, a norm at all levels (so no whining).  Multiple calls if you manage multiple projects.  No holiday party, but holiday breakfast or lunch or team meal outting.  Management is not shy about asking people to work over weekends, long weekends and holidays.  Promotion by luck, some are fast/just right, some are slow depending on manager, management group and department.  Little to no additional stock incentive year over year unless if you are in top 5-8%.  No pay time off tracking.

headline: It really depends on your role and what product you work on.
pros: Please note—I can really only speak as someone who worked on an acquired product. If you're working in Palo Alto at the headquarters, it seems like there are many smart, driven people on campus. The posted company values are great. VMware is very charitable and their actions prove it. All employees are given a certain amount of money they can donate to a charity of their choice each year. The work/life balance has been great, but it's also a bit of a con—it's only because no one is really ever in the office.
cons: Working on an acquired product is painful. The team is currently unmotivated and has no morale, due to many factors. One huge one is VMware really didn't pay attention to the product until things got really bad and they had to step in. I don't know if it's the same working on one of the actual "flagship" products vs. a product from an acquisition. I am not an engineer but I have managers who just don't know how to manage non-engineers. If you're a designer, be very cautious of this place. When it comes to understanding of design, it's extremely painful having both PMs and engineers who have never worked with designers. And as for career growth, I actually don't see any here. Also, nepotism was a huge issue in our office! People with 1-2 years experience were put in senior positions simply because they were friends with the hiring manager. It's definitely been a messy acquisition.

While I fully support equality in the workplace, vmWomen does not encourage its members to seek equality, it flat-out encourages its members to pursue gender-based preferential treatment. - Good opportunities to develop products used widely by enterprises.
- Highly skilled and talented engineers. Many folks from IITs.
- Company is into product development around SDDC & SDN which is billion dollar market.
- Flexible work hours.
cons:
- Work life balance not that great.
- Unlike other product based companies, no perks/benefits apart from fixed salary.
- Not very rewarding wrt expectations your manager would have from you.

headline: Outsourcing Canadian jobs to Costa Rica
pros: office culture, fair wages, leadership was great, intelligent people, nice perks like lunch, fun atmosphere, great customer service team until they outsourced to costa rica with no notice
cons: moved customer service & licensing to costa rica with no notice to employees and no opportunity to find another position within the company, they just called everyone into a meeting and said we were all out of a job and then stood outside handing us boxes to clean out our desks and told us to leave immediately, not a fair way to treat employees that put in their best effort for the company

headline: Love being here!
pros: Good pay, good people to work with and work for, good product, good campus (best I've ever worked at), good attitudes. Management keeps their eyes on what the market needs -- and doesn't need.
cons: Only, only, only complaint is the traffic on 85 and 280, especially in the evening commute. Surface streets sometimes better. That does affect the work-life balance some, as it induces people not to leave until 7PM.

headline: Great Company to work for
pros:
time-off policies
great campus
good food in the caffeteria
cons:
too many mid-level managers
half-hearted implementation of agile development practices
inexperienced management
career advancement a bit unclear

headline: Learning Experience
pros:
- Energetic, intelligent, and fun people are everywhere and in every department. There is are people of all cultures and backgrounds which makes for a very dynamic and diverse work environment.
- Great opportunity for younger employees to take on responsibility that they may not have had a chance to do at other companies
- Products are exciting and in-demand. AirWatch provides a great opportunity to work on the cutting edge of mobile technology.
- Benefits have improved every year and I expect this to continue since being acquired by VMWare.
- Atlanta office is in a nice location - accross the street from Marta and close to several stores, restaurants, and a mall
- Christmas parties are always awesome
cons:
- Management has, at times, had a micromanagement problem. It seems that they are afraid to trust their employees make good decisions. I will grant that this micromanagement may have been necessary at one point with a large amount of young and inexperienced employees, but now several experienced managers have been brought in and should be trusted in their decision making
- I found the open floor plan to be more distracting than helpful. It was often to difficult to work on tasks that required concentration due to constant distractions and interruptions.
- Policies are constantly changing. This is due to the large growth and acquistion that AirWatch has recently gone through, but it makes it very difficult to complete tasks when processes and policies change every two weeks
- Unrealistic timelines are often given to customers without first consulting with product teams on prior commitments and other timelines.  This results in low quality work or "band-aid" fixes that will just have to be reworked later. This is changing with the VMWare acquisition as VMWare is putting a strong focus on quality

headline: Smart people, some interesting work, not all of which are well organized, directed, and focussed
pros: Work in some groups is pretty leading edge. Lots of smart people. Flexibility on work hours and working from home. Pleasant physical work environment.
cons: Work in some groups is not so leading edge. Lots of hard-to-evolve software lying around. Development and introduction of tools to help developers get their jobs done has stagnated somewhat. Sometimes developers with not such terrific skills make choices that should have been (but weren't) made under the supervision or review of developers with better skills.

headline: Market share has gone to their head
pros: Generous salary, good cross section for people with diverse skills, tremendous client install base.
cons: No on-boarding, little training, HR is completely absent. Product is a commodity and new offerings are not a robust as advertised. Management appears to scared of EMC, AWS and the market in general. California dreaming has taken it toll, company is not driven to succeed and if you are miss aligned you can find yourself on the outside looking in.

headline: Love to work here
pros: Good Culture, Nice people to work with
cons: Depends on your salary negotiation

headline: software engineer
pros: great company, good co workeers and management. willing to work with schedules
cons: work life balance needs to be improved

headline: Managment, Agile, whats that?
pros: Your fellow coworkers are the best thing about this job.  You will make friends that will last a lifetime, but the only other thing is the casual environment.
cons:
This review is mainly for people looking to go into R&D at Airwatch but still applies to most of the company. 


The on-boarding is a week full of nonsense. It is 100% sales. How often will you need to give a sales pitch as a member of the R&D team? It would make a lot more sense if they tailored the training to one day of overall AW history, then Console basics, than finally your department. 

At Airwatch if you accept an offer for QA you do not decide where you will be placed. 

For example, If you have worked for Apple for 3 years and have a lot of experience debugging iOS applications, you will be placed on a windows mobile team. You are placed where you are needed not based on your strengths. Be prepared to move a lot too, after working on your first team, you will be relocated to another when half of their team decides they have had enough. 

You will be lucky however if you get one of the two actual competent managers for QA. 
Those two are active within their team and actually work, while the others sit around "handing out tasks" and try to come up with processes that will just make your life harder. 

In all honestly the R&D team is a tornado of 10 people actually working while the rest complain about how young their team is and that they are bored.  If you happen to be one of the people that work then you will not get any rewards or compensation aside from maybe a thank you from your customers support ticket . Their QA is about as flat as it gets. If you want to move up someone needs to leave and I can bet the person looking for the promotion will be the one to leave. 

That brings me to their attrition rate. ~50% of the people at AW have been with the company for less than a year. This is not because "Our employees are learning so much that they move on." It is because the management and amount of work are ridiculous for the "compensation" you will be getting. Turnover is high for a reason, and it is not a positive one. 

Workload is insane and unrealistic as many people on here have said. There is always some customer issue and YOU WILL be pulled away from your current task to work on it. That being said, you will be split across 1000 things to do and nobody will take that into account. You will have PMs jumping down your throat while your "Lead" will be giving you some made up task to validate their position. No one understands that you are being pulled in six different directions which causes you to have to stay late almost everyday.  It is not uncommon to have a 10+ hour day or to work on weekends while in QA. This would be fine if management put in the same amount of work.

You will be splitting work with the India team, but don't expect your lead to treat them like equals. For the Atlanta team, India is there to take blame when something isn't completed. They are not valued like they should be, much like most of the company.  

Huge lack of professionalism, you CAN NOT come gossip about how someone just had an awful interview and was "a complete waste of my time, and a total idiot." 

Management is the absolute worst part about this company. All they want to do is put their hands in as many cookie-jars as they can just so they can say "I had a part in this."  Office politics are at an all time high.  Most will not listen to their team for new processes or more efficient ways to do things. 

You will learn a lot don't get me wrong but here is the most likely scenario. 

You will probably work here for about a year, realize just how awful it is and then leave.

headline: Know what your getting into
pros: They have a Friday bash where they cater in food from local eateries, They provide free drinks and snacks, casual atmosphere (wear shorts and flip flops). They have some great employees. This could be an awesome place to work with a few needed improvements. They will train you on esxi / vsphere and you could gain needed skills. They encourage you to give to charities and will give you time to volunteer. Nice office environment it wasn't a bad atmosphere to work in.
cons: It's a Call Center, supervisors / managers don't really care about your success, sink or swim, high turnover, If a customer doesn't like your answer they can D-Sat you for any reason valid or not. We were told not to ask the escalation engineers for assistance since they were too busy. We were told to ask our peers or google if we needed assistance. I knew as much or more than my peers so this was no help. The techs that had been there awhile are on the phone so they cant help. This leaves you hanging on the phone with no way to help the customer. You have to get an exception from a manager to leave for more than 5 minutes to use the restroom during your call queue. We supported non VMware equipment and was told to figure it out. If the issue was a blue coat proxy misconfiguration we had to figure out how to configure it on the fly whether you had experience with the product or not. You have to sign non-solicit agreement which goes 1 year after you leave VMware which may inhibit your ability to find other employment.

headline: OK company - needs a regime change
pros: Open atmosphere, little micromanagement and  flexible hours in R&D. VMware's acquisition is starting to have a somewhat good impac .
cons:
Product Management department is filled with completely inexperienced people from support side. 
Company does not make money and VMware is now seeing this as well which is now resulting in cutbacks and hiring freezes across different department . 
They've hired a giant group of freshers straight out of school because they are cheap and they will do as they are told. Same formula was used at Manhattan Associates This is a good plan to capture good market share but horrible for product quality which shows in forms of bugs and hotfixes across all products.

headline: The golden years are over
pros: Very good work/life balance. Salary and benefits are also good at VMware. It's great for people with families/kids as there are many activities on a nice campus in Palo Alto.
cons:
Lack of professional/technical growth, but also lack of advancement or growth opportunities within your career.  
A lot of manager in middle management were bad engineers and got promoted to where they can't do much damage. But without proper training they end up being bad managers as well.
Experience is very specific to a team with some of the teams having some really incompetent engineers. Processes are broken, don't exist at all, are very antiquated and worst of all: resistant to change.
Customers are becoming increasingly dissatisfied with even the core products.

headline: Fun place to be with, innovative company. This company is growing in the mobile device management and does not compare
pros: If you are a motivated software developer person and can grow a book of business with a great company culture - this is the place to do it. Yes many prospects are taken but if you are creative and willing to put in some additional effort, you can make six-figure earnings within the first 3 years.
cons: Indeed is a good company. Its success and growth have been increasing dramatically - YOY numbers are pretty crazy. It is highly unlikely that you'll ever experience a start up gain such success again. It's pretty amazing to see, and honestly, pretty fun to be a part of.

headline: Shame on you!
pros:
Good solution and easy to sell
Very strong technical team
Good salary
cons:
Favoritism is widely practiced in Airwatch.  Management consistently offers some employees the best and most highly-regarded projects, even though those employees do not perform well enough to deserve them. 

Company morale is very low. No matter what you do, your efforts won’t be rewarded if you’re not one of the favored few that often will try to frustrate your activity.

Do not expect human resources personnel  to conduct an investigation: they have a mortgage to pay.

A lot of things are compromised in this process and it is a slap in the face of those who have dignity, integrity, and the commitment needed for their work.

headline: Only skill you learn is how to manage stress.
pros:
great coworkers/friends
Fun parties 
Casual wear
cons:
Horrible management , nothing is for certain, no one can make up their mind about best practices so it is constantly changing. managers are too busy in meetings and customer issues to actually manage. Most managers came into their position by luck as the company grew so rapidly and are not qualified to lead (i.e no people/management skills) 

training. The onboarding is sales oriented, and after that you are basically thrown in the fire(tradefloor) and moved around to where they need a body. 

Once you are hired you are treated as a warm body, not an employee with skills and assets. They don't utilize employees' knowledge and experience effectively and QA is a flat organization, where 90% of people are only hired to do manual mobile app test, AKA press buttons on a phone. Most QAs are not gaining any useful technical skills through this experience.

Workload is insane and unrealistic. No work life balance. There is always some fire/customer issue that needs attention now. it is a joke to call R&D agile. 

A lot of un-professionalism,  where people talk crap about/to  each other, It is the result of giving a bunch of kids fancy titles and power. A lot of room for slacking, 10% of the QAs carry the wight of the department while the others come in and go as they please and goof around. No one is really tracked.  There is no repercussions for un-professionalism and not doing your job.

pros:
Good starter job
Young people
good learning experince
cons:
Low pay
long hours
hard boss
